reviewText: Since there's no chance in hell anyone's going to see this review, I guess there's no point in me telling you that this is objectively one of the greatest roleplaying experiences in video games ever. There is also no point in me telling you that white wolf unarguably makes the greatest vampires and one of the darkest atmospheres in any kind of game, just as there is no point in telling you that this is the kind of game that has to be experienced because we will probably never get another game like this again. And since nobody can see this, there's definitely no chance anyone will ever know that I personally recommend pirating this 100% so you don't accidentally fund a terrible publisher that ruined an amazing development team. But since this is just a review, you can make your own decisions.

reviewText:
Don't forget to grab the unofficial patch by Wesp5 (updated until now!) who fix a TON of bugs and restore unreleased content.
One of the best rpg I've played so far. A masterpiece.

To put it simply: Fantastic story, amazing voice acting, great atmosphere, loving soundtrack, multiple ways to complete missions, dialogue changes depending on clan, high replay value and multiple endings.
Combat mechanics are a bit odd and outdated but whatever.

Highly recommended to all rpg fans.

reviewText:
This is not Twilight. This is not Dracula. This is not Anne Rice. This is not Buffy. This is World of Darkness.

Vampire: TMB's world is mysterious and complex, rich with lore from White Wolf Publishing's WoD tabletop games. The quests are memorable, characters desperate, locations varied, and character customization extensive. It is easily one of the best written RPGs ever published, right up there with the Fallout series.

I would blindly recommend this to anyone remotely into verbose games. NPCs have very unique insights into the world they live in, and constantly share their philosophies with the player (the voice acting is excellent). Naturally, anyone who finds themselves bored after a few paragraphs of hearing NPCs talk should skip this game.

Edit:

I should have probably also mentioned that although VTMB's writing is stellar, there is also quite a bit of combat. The game strikes a nice balance between letting you feel like a ridiculously overpowered rampaging creature of the night, and a mere shadow of other, elder vampires: some fights will be hilariously easy (especially against human foes), others will be tremendously difficult (high-level supernatural enemies, yikes!). Character creation and levelling up is very comprehensive, and should be a joy for anyone who likes putting thought into how they will play the game.

Please note that the game was extremely buggy when released, and is moderately difficult to run on modern PCs. See here for post-installation instructions: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2025035

Shoutout to modder Wesp5 for keeping this game playable even 10 years after its original release!

reviewText:
This is by far one of my favorite games. I seriously play it at least once every year or so. VTMB is not your basic Vampire RPG. The game allows you to switch between first and third person, features both melee and ranged combat, and allows you mutliple paths to any of your goals. This is set in White Wolf's World of Darkness universe. If you are familiar with table-top RPGs and the World of Darkness, good, if not that is okay (I was not).

The World of Darkness is your basic modern urban fantasy universe. You the player take the part of a newly created vampire thrust into a world of intrigue and darkness where ancient vampires pull the strings of humanity and each other in ever-shifting alliances and plans. The game allows you a high degree of customization, when creating your character you can choose from one of 6 clans, which feature different superpowers that your character can build as you level. There are no classes, you build your stats how you want them. Your quests almost all feature multiple paths to completion. Need to kill a vampire hunter? Well you can talk your way into her place of work (if you got the speech skills), sneak around the pack and pick some locked doors (if you have the stealth and lockpicking skills), maybe hack some computers to put the place into lockdown and get civilians to leave the area (if you have the hacking skills), or maybe you just want to kick in the front door and go to work with your katana/shotgun/teeth&claws. In this game there are mutilple paths to your goal. A few different endings (choose one of the factions or yourself), and enless playthrough ability. Visit the community forums for this game and download the fanmade patches, they will give you extra quests, clans and plug some bugs.

Seriously. I can't reccomend this game highly enough.

reviewText:
Firstly, you will need the unofficial patch to play this (so here it is: http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647.) The original devs were pushed to release this early by activision, thus it was very buggy. BUT that said, this is easily one of the best RPGs ever concieved. (Also ignore the low play time, for some reason when I installed the patch on my last system the patch only worked if I launched it off of steam, my play time probably numbers in the hundreds of hours.)

So, Pros

-The Role Playing aspect of this game is very deep, I haven't played a game in a long time that rivals it. You can play as one of 7 vampire 'clans' (which are basically sub species of a sort.) Each clan has it's own unique skill sets, meaning each clan have strengths and weaknesses. Whether it's the toreador with their seductive ability to manipulate practically anyone, the nosferatu, who can stealth their way into just about anywhere, or the brujah who are your more naturally brawling vampire type. Each of the seven clans has distinct strengths and distinct weaknesses.

-Skill specialisation means that you can't be a jack of all trades, if you commit to being a silver tongued devil that talks their way into and out of everything, then you won't be as good at fighting. The opposite is also true, and considering that being good at persuasion/seduction doesn't result in bloodshed this means your vampire will naturally be able to accomplish things that a violent vampire would not, again the opposite is true.

-Because of this, the game has vast replayability, as even a slightly different playstyle results in quite a different story.

-Speaking of replayability, Malkavians are amazing, but they are insane, I would not recommend playing them on your first playthrough. Nosferatu can also be really fun, but are hard to play because you cannot be seen by mortals.

-Leads me on to another important point. The Maquerade itself. The Masquerade is a conspiracy of vampire culture that maintains the illusion to mortals that they don't exist. Meaning that you can't behave in a supernatural way in certain areas, lest you violate the masquerade and incur the discipline of vampire culture. Certain abilities can still be used, depending on whether they are discreet or not, this is another layer of depth to the roleplaying system, as some vampire clans are naturally more capable in masquerade areas. For me personally, I am an avid player of the Toreador (It appeals to the part of me that adore the Anne Rice books.) This clan plays exceptionally well in masquerade areas because they are the most 'human' of all the vampire types, whereas the Nosferatu for example cannot be seen in these areas due to their appearance.

-The Characters in this are not necessarily believable (some are very convincing, some are less so,) but either way the characters are... well... characters... You will love them, and you will love them a lot, the voice acting is amazing, and so is the facial animation, (which is ridiculously expressive, notice I say expressive, not necessarily realistic.) Dialogue options are also insanely awesome in a bethesda before bethesda kind of way.

Cons

-Combat (it pains me to mention it, but I have to.) The combat in this game doesn't bother me, but it can be a bit twitchy. Don't worry, we're not talking morrowind levels of twitchy, but it's a little twitchy nonetheless. But it's very easy to overlook because everything else in this game is so on point.

-I should probably mention this as a con, but I just see it as an inevitable mechanic: There are points in the game where you simply cannot avoid intense combat. This can really annihilate a social vampire, so it's good to invest the odd point into ranged weapons once every now and then (because ranged weapons are generally the best thing to deal with the late game combat.) This seems to put some people off the game but it really doesn't bother me that much, and again i'm willing to overlook it because everything else in the game is done so damn well.

In summary this game is one of the gems of the rpg genre, and you can't call yourself a fan of roleplaying games if you haven't checked this out. it is THE example of a flawed masterpiece; something which had so much ambition and very nearly lived up to it all but fell just a little short. But in spite of this the game is still way above average, and very close to perfection. And it represents something that more games developers should aspire to, because this game went for the moon, and damn nearly got there. Games aren't this ambitious anymore, they don't try to be this unusual any more, and if something did in this generation of gaming, it would truly be a masterpiece.

reviewText:
Bought this game while on sale thinking it was gonna be pretty so-so. I'd heard things about Vampire: The Masquerade before, but never actually tried it. Boy am I glad I did. This game is like a hidden gem. The graphics are outdated, but what else can you expect from a game that's over 10 years old? If you enjoyed being able to make your own story in Dragon Age or Mass Effect, you may enjoy Vampire: The Masquerade, as it allows you to choose conversation options and shape your character's path.

Although you can't customise the appearance of your character (other than clothing), you can choose between 7 different races of vampires of each gender, each with different abilities. Other clothing options can later be bought from the different locations throughout the game, each giving more armour and a different look from the last.

The story begins with your character and the opposite gender version of your character's race getting 'friendly', and your character will be Embraced (turned). Unfortunately, your sire has commited a violation of the Masquerade by Embracing someone without permission, and is executed for their crimes. Left sireless, after an intervention by the vampire Nines you are allowed a chance to live, but you must 'serve' LaCroix, the prince. During the story, you'll learn what Sabbat, Camarilla, Kuel'jin and many other things are. But I won't spoil the story for you, go play it yourself.

The downside of this game is that, in order to play it, you must do a few things. There are a few bugs that will not allow the game to play on Steam. To combat this, you must run Steam in administrator mode and change the compatibility properties of Vampire: The Masquerade. I changed the properties to run the program in compatibility mode for Windows XP (Service Pack 3), and disabled visual themes and desktop compositions. Doing these steps should allow you to run the game. But that's not all. Even though this game is old, there are still unofficial patches being made for it. I recommend installing Wesp's unofficial patch 8.9 at least, as this will fix the resolution error with the game and make the interface clear instead of blurry. Each patch contains everything from the patches before, so you can install the latest one without missing anything. The patches fix a lot of bugs and add things to the game. However, with each patch you must make it a fresh install, delete everything from the patches before (this includes your save files) and replace them with the new patch. The game may crash if you do not do this. You should replace the folder named Vampire inside your Vampire: The Masquerade Bloodlines folder with the patch folder, which will also be named Vampire. You must also disable the auto updates for the game in the Steam properties, or it may install the old official patch over your unofficial one.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game. Some of the boss fights were quite challenging, there is a lot of side quests and missions to keep you occupied, and you can choose your character's destiny in the world of darkness. You can choose to be a saucy seductress, a badmouthed badass, anything really. And if you choose a Malkavian, you'll have different conversation options than the other races, as Malkavian's have a sort of split personality and insanity. I wish there was a sequel or something. Sucks that the World of Darkness MMO based on this universe was recently cancelled as I was looking forward to it, but what can you do.

~ 9/10 ~

reviewText:
TL;DR - you can suck blood and dance in clubs 11/10

Oh Vampire: the Masquerade - Bloodlines, you were and still are ahead of your time. You had a great soundtrack before great soundtracks were necessary.

You have an incredibly absorbing world full of darkness and gothic tropes that are executed flawlessly and make you root for characters that would otherwise haunt our dreams.

You have the Masquerade violations that can kill my game regardless of how powerful I think I am. No law like the Vampire law.

You make vampires and other creatures of the night the terrifying, evil creatures they are instead of love-sick babies.

You have a haunted house level that puts some modern horror games to shame.

You have the ability to dance before dancing in clubs was cool in RPGs.

You have a plot that makes my blood pressure rise and fall like I'm being drained by a hideous Nosferatu.

You have a LOT...of bugs.

But,

You have us, dear Vampire...you have us to patch you and bring you to a new generation on Steam.

R.I.P Troika and long live the Masquerade.

reviewText:
Many moons ago a developer named Troika Games released Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines yet through its lifetime it has managed to linger behind the curtain despite the generally unrivalled quality it bears. I wish to open the curtain and propose you to join me in this ‘sombre dance’.

To start off you get to choose between 7 quite varied classes, called clans. Want to play as a Nosferatu and deal massive damage but have the sewers as your main travel path, or would you rather be of the noble kind, a master of eloquence and persuasion but lack physical prowess? Or maybe you fancy the clinically insane that suffers from schizophrenia? I chose the clinically insane because... well as if you wouldn't...and it turned out I chose well because the Malkavian is indubitably one of the most creative character you can play in video games.

From the start, you'll notice major technical issues and design decisions that indicate the game was released on its last legs. Their dream nearly did indeed turn to dust as the company went bust soon after its release. In spite of this, the team managed to make a game that unfortunately today is a merely an ash, but a game that still to this day goes against the grain. Eventually an (unofficial) patch was released that made the game much more playable.

It takes a very conventional approach to customization. On offense you can choose to specialise in guns, unarmed, melee and powers known as disciplines. The defensive counterparts also exist. Each clan has its own set of disciplines that you can specialise in. In addition you can level up skills including hacking, lock picking, intimidation, seduction, research etc and some of these skills add extra dialogue options which can lead to otherwise unavailable rewards. Loot isn’t as abundant as in Bethesda games for example but it exists in moderate amounts. The game features your standard health bar and a blood bar for good measure. You fuel your blood bar by using civilians as sustenance. The refuel rate varies on the civilian type and caution is required since if you get caught you lose masquerade points and once that reaches zero you lose the game for reasons you can find out for yourself. Additionally killing civilians (for example) will lower your humanity and once that reaches a certain point your character does bad things. The graphics are dated but definitely passable.

These aforementioned issues, these run of the mill customization options are ultimately trivial because the game manages to supersede its faults completely as it ironically isn't devoid of spirit and soul. The game induces perturbation, states of uneasiness, disorientation and even sheer unadulterated terror in both expected and unexpected locations that’ll make you just wish you could give it a maniacal final vale and go make a sandwich while playing Skyrim or something. It isn't all doom and gloom though. This atmosphere, this ‘sombre dance’ can quickly shift to an upbeat vampiric club rave (literally). Of course this tonal shift is entirely at your digression but it's this type of juxtaposition that makes the sinister and foreboding moments all the more significant. The game has quite a few unique takes on conventional missions and a cast of absolutely impeccable characters. These characters can be usually manipulated depending on the clan you choose. For example If you choose the insane schizophrenic, you can use mind control on people to make weird gigglies and other disturbing lines come out their facehole which consequently will make gigglies come out of your facehole. To please the masses there’s also tons of philosophical yet hilarious one liners too.

As an encore the game washes you with its masterful soundtrack. It’s an eclectic bunch of tunes that amplify the various moods you’ll feel in the game. Whether it’s ominous or calm, frantic or upbeat it does its job. At times there’s an absence of music where ambience is created by the sound of the world around you which in my mind is a soundtrack in itself. This natural ambience can be felt in many places but for the majority of people it will be most memorable in the Ocean House Hotel, considered by those who’ve experienced it as one of the most frightening areas in video games, alongside Shalebridge Cradle from Thief Deadly Shadows. No other game has matched the level of trepidation I felt in The Ocean House Hotel.

Upon release, a significant portion of those who played it hated it because it was marred by its technical issues of which it became infamous for but the biggest cause of its demise was its release alongside Half Life 2. Luckily the game is still on sale today so bless your blood vessels by biting into this magical game like the pale lotus eater that you know you are because once you are done, you'll realise that this product, in this large market where the generic usually flourish most, is an ensemble of special silence and Troika's genuine, bittersweet farewell kiss.

Mod Recommendations: Unofficial patch: http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647

reviewText: Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines is a RPG from publisher Activision and developed by Troika Games. For years I'd been hearing from various people about  how great this title is and now that I've played it I must totally agree. Roleplaying games are my bread and butter so this title definitely delivers with its core RPG elements. You create your character and as you progress through the game you acquire experience points which you can then distribute to many different skills and abilities thus allowing you to customize your vampire to your liking and particular style of play be that close or long ranged combat or stealth. The game is action oriented and played in either a first or third person perspective similiar to say Fallout 3 or New Vegas. Graphically the game is dated especially compared to many of the titles from recent years but with the addition of the unofficial patches by Wesp5 and various others you can update the title with high resolution textures and an abundance of bug fixes and enhancements that make it look fairly great for a game that was released so long ago. I myself am a fan of games with retro and outdated graphics and this title just has a nice style to it that fits the dark and forboding theme perfectly. Even better, the dialogue that I've been having throughout the game is one of my favorite aspects of the title as the voice acting is top notch and done so very well. Released in 2004 this game also seems to have been doing things slightly ahead of its time...things that we take for granted as they are very common place in the games of today. Pound for poind I'm loving this title and plan to spend many hours playing it so it is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!\n\nP.S.-Thanks to Section Nine http://steamcommunity.com/id/Section9/ for providing the links to the patches for the game.

reviewText:
Vampire; the Masquerade - Bloodlines

Before purchasing please note you will need to download an Unofficial Patch to fully get the game to work.

Storyline, lore and depth is heavy in this game. When you first lay eyes on it, it might be an eye sore, but trust me. Start to sink your fangs into the first few victims and get lost into the twisted personal horror game that lets you cling to your humanity while witnessing unGodly, unspeakable things... or let loose and become the monster you always wanted to be all the while walking the thin red line of not breaking too many Kindred laws.

The RPG element comes from the table top version of the game, point in intel, point in strength, point in charisma or melee, the concept is easy to use for beginners and easy to follow if you hover your mouse over any stat. It will tell you exactly what other stats benifit from your choices. Lacking in Hacking? Lacking in lock picking? (Dues Ex - like skills) Just add points to whatever helps you make you better at what you like doing.

Game play: When you start you pick a clan, each clan has their own strengths, their own weaknesses. Adding to the replay value of the game. Brawl your way, punk your enemies into submission, lie or whisper sweet nothings into the humans' ears to manipulate them into giving you what you want. Stealth your way through the city via sewers and back alleys, stick to the shadows - or walk among the humans and other vampires as their superior. It's all up to you.

Lots of side quests and though the world is not too vast (hence the game was made in 2004) you will have plenty to do with the portions of the city you have access to. Some you will need to gain specific skills, others you will get to as the game progresses.

The music is awesome. 90's and early 2000's gothic/rock, dark metal music. Will be looking for the OST of this game.

Voice acting, Jeanette! And many others. Even a popular actor from the TV show Futurama voice acted in this. Jeanette's voice actress did a role for Harley Quinn as well. Love her work! One of the strongest parts of this game is conversing with the NPCs. Some are funny, others will make you annoyeed, but none will be boring. Certain powers and certain social skills will effect how NPCs interact and react to you. Some you will need to threaten, if your threat is high enough, some you will have to persuade, others you have to flirt with, and some (if you pick clan Malkavian) you can just talk crazy talk with them. All adding to the depth of each NPC and some making you wish you could talk with them all night long.

The game is a Horror game, and some jump scares, but the feeling I get from playing the game... CREEP FEST. The atmosphere of the game when you get into a haunted house, or exploring a mad house, or going into a den of those trying to hurry the end of the world... and the sewers! It will make you think twice about opening a manhole, in real life and in game.

Over all this game is a CULT CLASSIC. If anything, get it and play it so when you nerd it out with your friends online or in person, you can give them lots of bloody tales of your own experiances in Vampire - Bloodlines.

9.5 / 10 Play it! Worth every penny at full price and at 75% off. No reason not to on a big sale!

reviewText:
Great opportunity in the Halloween sale to pick up this legendary game very inexpensively.  I highly recommend this game, at least then nobody can say you haven't played it.

Upgrading your character is pretty much the same as the pen and paper RPG, which itself is very straightforward.

The atmosphere of the game is excellent and not at all like the whiny vampires of recent genre pieces.

Characters and story are pretty memorable, with a couple of npcs changing and upgrading depending on the choices you make within game - I can't say much more about that without spoiling the story, but good luck to you with achieving the best results!

Technically, I would expect most pc to be able to handle this game; it's a bit poorly optimised which is understandable if you know the games' history.

Overall, very highly reccomended!

reviewText:
My Review on VTMB
Tl:dr Awesome game with (in my eyes) no downside, high replayability, nice characters and a dark story/atmosphere. If you are not sure if you want it, wait for a sale. If you have no problem with older games in your library and love RPG’s, get it instantly and stop reading.

Now to the main part of the Review....

So I was thinking that I need a new RPG to play. It should have a nice story, good gameplay and some open choices for the player. After a long time searching I found Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines. I waited for a long time, before grabbing it on sale and what can I say....I love it.

First things first as you may read in other reviews, this game has many bugs. Luckily there is a nice Community that fixes them and brings patches for the game. Before you play it make sure you download the latest patch found here: http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647.

Now let’s start with The Review itself, why do I love this game so much? First, it is inspired by the Vampire: The Masquerade Pen and Paper, and the universe of it, a universe that is deep and complex, and instantly took a place in my heart, where Vampires live along mortal people with rules they have to keep, called the Masquerade. In that world, there are 7 playable and some more (Npc only) Clans that all play in a different way and even have a small impact on your story.
The Clans are called: Brujah, Gangrel, Malkavian, Nosferatu, Toreador, Tremere and Ventrue. At the beginning you pick 1 of these, decide if you are female or male (sadly no more customization) and then you allocate your standard skill points" in your character sheet
date: whilst every clan has his own abilities and different bonuses on some of the attributes.\n\nThen the Story starts. After a pretty
recommended: long but well-made intro sequence you can control your character. The controls feel a bit strange at first and you may have to enable mouse look in the options to get a free camera

helpfulPercent: you switch to 1st person while using your ranged firearms. Also nice : most of your attributes increase more than 1 ability
votesHelpful: example: 1 point of dexterity will get you +1 lockpicking and +1 sneaking skill
votesTotal: strength will get you +1 unarmed and +1 melee and so on
votesFunny: so there are many different ways to design and actually play your character
commentsCount: which leads to the next point.\n\nThe Story has to my knowledge 5 endings
column16: that trigger with your final choice and your positioning to the factions (called sects)

column18: your actions that you make in the story "speak" for you.\n\nAnd finally The Difficulty...... I love it. The Disciplines between the clans are well balanced and with the right combination of Disciplines and weapons

reviewText: Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is my favourite RPG and my favourite game. If I try to be as objective as I possibly can, I can admit that other, better RPGs have come and gone; this is more of a personal preference. The last four or so missions are a bit too lengthy and also happen to be rubbish. I think there are more bad endings than there are good, but I really can't deny what a great time I was having up until those points. Let me preface this review by saying that I don't like Vampires. I never cared for them and I thought I would stay that way until the day I die. My opinion immediately changed within the first 20 minutes or so of playing this game; the vampires are so badass. Troika's approach to Vampires is definitely interesting. Set in 21st century Los Angeles, the Vampires coexists with man and are required to uphold the masquerade" by keeping their existence a secret.\n\nThe game begins with you selecting one of seven vampire clans

reviewText:
This game is a cult classic.

You should be warned that this game is broken and will not function on most modern machines.  There is an Unofficial Patch made by Wesp5 that fixes nearly all issues with the game and also adds new content.

Based on the board game, and sequel to Redemption, you play as a fledgling Vampire in California.  The story starts as you create your character.  Here you choose your background, bloodline, and gender.  Backgrounds change your stats slightly and your powers as a vampire will differ depending on your bloodline.  Some bloodlines have some side effects, however.

The best examples are Malkavians and Nosferatu.  Malkavians are insane and schizophrenic.  You'll talk like a crazy person, hear voices in your head and see things other people don't see.  Nosferatu are cursed in a different way as they can't be seen by humans without violating the masquerade.  This does not make it impossible to beat the game as a Nosferatu, because the main quest NPC's will still be approachable.

The masquerade is a system in the game where if you get 5 bad marks it's game over and you'll be executed by your peers.  You earn bad marks by displaying certain powers in public or are seen feeding.  You can redeem yourself if you have bad marks by protecting the masquerade.  This usually involves killing someone who is speaking  too much or who isn't playing it safe like all other good little vampires should.

Graphics are decent and passable.  The game is an older game, so don't expect mind blowing visuals.  City hubs are fairly small but there's a lot to find if you set your mind to it.  There are some nice facial animations that you won't even see in games nowadays which adds to the immersion.  There's also several mods for the game to add atmosphere and even more depth to the classes.

Gameplay is basic.  You shoot things, you smash things.  You talk to people, you kill people.  There are extra dialog options if you level your seduction, intimidation, or persuassion skills.  These skills can be vital to completing some quests perfectly.  You can also recieve bonuses from certain NPC's for having them at the required level at certain points in conversation.

You gain experience from doing quests and you level up to gain strength, wisdom, guile, skill, and become more attractive.  If you're sexy enough you get free hookers! Just like IRL! =P

The beginning of the game will mostly be fetch quests, with a few baddies to either slaughter or let live.  It's a game where you can put the fate of nearly everyone around you in your hands.  Being good is rewarded with extra perks like your very own slave ghoul girl, or an extra item/money/experience.  There's also a decent but easy stealth system that's based on how many points you have in stealth.  If you max out stealth, are in the shadows and crouch you're pretty much invisible.  There are also assassinations you can do with each weapon while stealthed and behind your victim.  My favorite is the baseball bat.  :)

Audio is very good as well.  Just make sure you turn Environmental Effects off or there will be a constant echo.  Voice actors are all top notch and AAA grade ones that you'll know if you've heard them before.

There are some very good mods for this game available as well.  My favorite being the original Unofficial Patch Plus, but there are other that increase the difficulty of the game and add new quests and bloodlines to choose from.  When installing these big mods you need to remember that they aren't compatible with eachother.  E.G. Final Nights mod will not work with Camarilla Edition nor with either work with the Unofficial Patch.  Both mods have an Older version of the Unofficial patch that come with it, which still fixes a lot of bugs.  There's also several mods  that are still being produced constantly by fans.  Every now and then you should check up and see what new mods are out to keep you coming back for more.

All in all, if you are in need of a good RPG that's open world with a lot of freedom and are tired of Fallout 3/NV, Skyrim, etc.  Then you should definately check this game out.  Especially if it's on sale.  Well worth every penny spent.

reviewText:
The stronger points of the game are that it has a fantastically dark atmosphere, believable and often intense characters (something which alot of games lack), and a solid storyline that does the game justice. Also, you choose at the beginning which bloodline (faction) you are part of, which will directly affect your relationships with the characters in-game, offering variation and replayablility, if you don't mind already knowing the storyline the second time through. Finally, the level design is very well done, giving varied and interesting locations that will keep your interest, no rampant cookie-cutter design here.

On the down side, it is a dated game, having been released in 2004, so you will probably only get the most out of it if you don't mind the avatars looking a bit blocky compared to what you might be used to. I'm sure it was 'fairly' close to cutting edge graphics in 2004, but if you can look past it, the game will suck you in and you won't notice.

It was mentioned that the game doesn't feel finished by one reviewer, and while I disagree, I can see why that might come up. The game is completely set at night, so far as I can remember, so you won't get the bustling city feel that daytime would bring, and also it doesn't have a huge amount of side quests that seem to pack into games these days (to cover up lack of original content), but there is plenty to keep you occupied.. you won't get bored.

Also, apparently the game was quite buggy at release. I'd used the official patch when I played it, and didn't come across any problems. I certainly didn't come close to checking on forums, as one or two others had, but everyone plays a game differently, and it's becoming standard practice to check forums rather than think a problem through, or work around it. Regardless, apparently the unofficial patch made by fans is the best, from what I gather.

Overall I greatly enjoyed the game and thought it to be underrated, definately a pleasant surprise. At no point did I get bored, even though there are many areas, nor did I question whether I'd see it through to the end, unlike quite a few games which get churned out. The storyline was interesting, and I found myself carefully watching the behaviour of all the characters, not quite sure who to trust, as it should be in a vampire underworld. The hotel level was especially spooky, I might add ;) good job on that. I only wish that there was a sequel.

reviewText:
Initial Note: Don't be fooled by my game time as shown by Steam. I own the boxed version and have completed it in excess of 5 times, so spent a fair few hours in this one.

A flawed but o-so beautiful gem. A game that is pure genius, oozes atmosphere and drags you in. If it wasn't for the bugs, clunky combat and lackluster final stretch of the game, it would be a masterpiece.... well, to be honest, it IS a masterpiece, in-spite of that.

An RPG at heart, built on the original Source engine, it is a game like no other. I have not played a game that pulled me in quite like this since, and I doubt I ever will do again. Its characters, story and the adult way in which it plays out is simply gaming gold. If you try it, I would highly recommend getting hold of the community patch - which fixes 95% of what was wrong with the game at launch.

Please, developers - give us more games like this.

Jimbo Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
There's only one reason to give this game a poor review:

IT DOES NOT WORK WITHOUT ONE OF THE UNOFFICIAL PATCHES YOU WILL HAVE TO DOWNLOAD AND INSTALL.

Now, this isn't a great hindrance, as you can find the guides to help you right here on Steam.  There are even guides that will aid you in getting the graphic-enhancing mods to work that come with one of the patches (I chose Wesp's Unoffical Patch since it seemed to contain more goodies).

Yeah, yeah, I know the game's developer's are out of business.  I know it 'only takes five minutes to install the patch'.  Doesn't really matter.

Someone is asking people to fork over $20 for a decade-old game (as of the time of this writing, you can get it for $5 though!), and someone is getting that money.  That 'someone' could at least update it with a patch of their own that is included in the purchase.  Whoever is getting paid for this game is relying on the cult status this game has achieved to put money in their pockets and giving their fans the middle finger as they do it.

Which is a shame because, what I've played so far, it's a great game.  Not top-notch, but pretty good for its niche.

Graphics:  They're a decade old and even with enhancements, it shows its age.  Animations are kind of stiff and clunky, and everything is sort of reminiscent of the way the original Blood Rayne looked.

Voice-Acting:  Some of it is Grade A, some of it is Grade F.  Pretty hit or miss, as usual with most games, your protagonist stays silent.  Nothing wowing here, except for how terrible some of it is.

Gameplay:  Pretty basic.  Forces you into third-person view whenever you do melee fights, which I find irritating.  I'd like it a lot more if I didn't have to see my own character's awkward flailing strikes.  There are some nice elements, such as your ability to be a silver-tongued rascal, or computer-hacking nerd, or lockpicking sneak really coming into play.  I also like how faithful they are to the source material, with Nosferatu having to stay hidden from humans, the rivalry war between Sabbat and Camarilla, etc.

Story:  It's nothing to sneeze at, but it's not quite as great as some people claim.  Your dialogue choices are often clunky and ridiculous, but the whole thing weaves together fairly well.

TL;DR:  Get it while it's on sale.  KNOW YOU WILL HAVE TO MANUALLY PATCH IT TO GET IT TO WORK.  DO NOT IGNORE ALL THE REVIEWS TELLING YOU THIS, THINKING IT WILL WORK ON YOUR RIG.

If whoever is making money off of selling this game would patch it themselves, I would give it a positive recommendation.

reviewText:
Do you want to know what is the greatest hidden gem that was harshly buried due to its rushed release, lack of sales, and bugs in the history of gaming? Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines is it.

I had this game standing alone in the backlog two years ago. I kept having strange sudden urges saying I need to play this game over and over again. I decided why the heck not. The game kept crashing and crashing. I found out it required community patches. Already had 300 of them... Wow, the community must be sooo dedicated. I wonder why? Hmm...

Now it finally ran smooth at the start. Boom, my life changed when I put my foot in the city of Santa Monica and met a memorable character named Smiling Jack. The atmosphere and the characters in the game were something I have never seen or experienced before in any games that blown me away. They were soooo freaking immersing that kept me hooked playing this game nonstop for two weeks. The story became remarkably darker, mind blowing, and emotional all at the same time. It was sooo well written and properly executed that I couldn't believe how good the whole thing is. The characters. The atmosphere and places to explore. The gameplay and RPG elements chosen for this game. The plot. EVERYTHING. So good. I do not want to spoil ANYTHING because you need to play this first.

The experience inspired me to complete few playthroughs with different clan and mods. The community and cult following are so dedicated that it's amazing. This game is a textbook example of a cult classic.

Excellent cult classic. I am proud to claim this game as my third favorite game of all time.

9.7 out of 10

reviewText:
Hands down, the best game I've ever played. It's dark and gritty without taking itself too seriously, filled with atmopshere and world-detail without playing like a fantasy encyclopedia. and you can roll around town dressed up as a pimp or a stripper. What more could you want from a game?

The best testimony of how fantastic this game is is undoubtedly the fans; Even though this game came out in 2004, there are still unofficial patches being developed and released as you read this. Never has a game been more loved, cherished, or enriched by its community. We're just lucky to be able to play it now, when all the bugs have been fixed by dedicated fans, compared to its initial release.

The game play is fairly simple and easy to access, though the variety of levels mean it never gets dull. You can shoot, tear, or bite your way through your enemies, and look like something straight out of a bondage fever dream/nightmare whilst doing it. The plot is genuinely gripping, with twists and turns I never saw coming, and the ending? The ending is just... f*** me. Well played, Bloodlines. Well played.

Storyline? Basically, you wake up a fledgling after a passionate night with your fanged lover, only to end up becoming a glorified slave of a grumpy french nobleman with a Napoleon complex and a damn nice suit. Be his ♥♥♥♥♥ for what feels like eternity. Blow ♥♥♥♥ up. The ranges of choices you're given are actually pretty impressive, and DO make a difference, unlike some franchises I can think of (*cough*Mass Effect*cough). Be sassy. Be crazy. Be sexy as hell. It's one of those games where you can truly be whoever you want.

Aside from appropriately dressed. No mod will ever give you that.
voteText: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
In a way this game (when you manage to run it with the unofficial patch) reminds me about Bathesda's Elder Scrolls series. It has small, more compact world because of the source engine I presume, but lots of content. I am mentioning Elder Scrolls for the solo purpose of saying that just like TES, VTM:B must be loved with all its flaws, bugs, errors and imperfections.
I honestly believe that Troika Games just had horrible luck as if universe screwed them up while they were creating the game.

Starting with engine itself, Troika used an unfinished Source Engine and had to work with it, adding their own code. Troika worked on the same engine that Half-Life 2 were even before the engine was shown publicly. In fact they had an agreement that they can't sell the game before the Half-Life 2 release.

After the engine came Activision. Even though Troika employers kept on working overtime on the game, Activision still rushed the release and cut off sponsorship of the game. So in the end we got ourselves a rushed, unpolished product that in fact was fixed and updated by fans for more than 11 years now.
And you might think thats it? Troika Games sold too little copies of the game to keep up afloat and ended up being closed. How did that happen if the game is so good as I keep on saying?

Bad luck.

Release date of the game is November 2004. What else happened in 2004 prior the November?
Unreal Tournament 2004, Far Cry, Sacred, Painkiller, Hitman: Contracts, Manhunt, Thief: Deadly Shadows,  Doom 3, Silent Hill 4: The Room, Sims 2, Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War, Star Wars: Battlefront, Myst IV: Revelation, Rome: Total War and many other awesome games. Year 2004 was an amazing year in the industry.

And you may think that with all that competition on the market VTM:B were safe since they released in November, while other games were earlier? Well, still bad luck Troika Games.

What happened in November in the PC game industry? (I am not mentioning games such as MGS3 and other console games since I am talking about PC)
CS:Source, Half Life 2, NFS: Underground 2, World Of Warcraft, Prince Of Persia: Warrior Within and so on. With all respect to Troika Games, they had no chance of wining a competition.

Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is probably one of my favorite games of all time. With all it's imperfections and glitches it delivers an amazing lore, story, humor and experience. Gameplay itself (fighting) is done horribly and sloppy though so don't expect to be blown away with it, dialoges is what makes it so special. Depending on the vampire clan you chose it can take you 3 or more walkthroughs to experience all the game aspects such as different approaches (stealth, fighting with magic or brute force, persuation/intimidation/seduction) and even a special, Malkavian clan walkthorugh. You see, Malkavians are insane vampires. And by insane I mean totally sick. When you play as a Malkavian character literally every dialogue line for you is changed in a mad/insane way. In fact you can have a dialog with a news reporter on your TV if you are playing as a Malkavian.

All and all, when playing this game keep in mind that it was released in 2004 and it has lots of flaws that modern games don't, but thats simply because people are always becoming better at what they do and creating videogames is not an exception.
voteText: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Okay, so I started playing this game about two years ago and only made it to the second location because the game is buggy as Hell and wasn't loading something that was an intergral part of one of my missions (so, I quit instead of starting over).

I recently replayed the game, all the way through, this time, and let me tell you: this game is fantastic.

I's an old game, sure, but it definitely holds up well. And in some ways, is vastly superior to some modern games. The graphics are a bit dated, but not horribly so. Again, I've played some modern games with worse. Voice acting is top-notch. The story and lore that surrounds the game is amazing and deep. You could spend hours just talking to NPCs because the lore is that involved and you may want to absorb it all. I hesitate to say characters are believable (I'm looking at you, Knox), but they're charming. Some are likeable, whereas others are easy to hate. Either way, they're all written well for the world they are in and really help to develop it. I found the Anarchs to be a much more relatable, realistic group than some of the others. That said, the members of the Anarchs are my favorite chraracters, so I could be biased.

Combat (especially melee) can be a bit clunky, but not impossible to handle. And, due to the various clans, it makes it very easy to find a playstyle that works best with what you like. This game transitions from a stealth/puzzle game, to a 3rd person hack and slash, to a 1st person shooter seamlessly, and allows the player to change up their playstyle on the fly.

Each clan has a very unique, rich story that surrounds them, which makes it fun to play multiple times in order to get a feel for all seven of them.

Some the levels are unsettling, or downright scary to go through. They're very atmospheric, with great audio and visuals. I would be lying if I said that there weren't some missions where I had to take my headphones off, or had to play during daylight hours while other people were around. There's one in particular where you don't even face any enemies, but the hair on the back of my neck still stands up every time I go through it.

My one main complaint is that VTMB is a game that hinges on the fact that your character might be a sexual creature, making it possible to sort of romance some of the characters. However, there is only one male NPC throughout the game who can be 'romanced', yet several females. I get that at the time, game companies thought  that female gamers were a rarety, so I don't really fault it too much.

reviewText:
Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is considered one of the classic PC RPGs. I've seen nothing but positive things about it, but to be honest, the cover art and the concept kind of warded me off of it. After all, vampires suck now.

Now, after 30 hours and having beaten the game, I can safely say it's one of the best games I've ever played.

It has a unique atmosphere, gothic without feeling forced, gritty and stylish. It takes what the modern take on the modern vampire is and makes it well... good. Great. Apparently, this is the norm for VTM (which I haven't played at Tabletop before). I would say its the best depiction of a modern vampire out there.

It's not all rosy, of course. This game doesn't pull any punches if you're not being careful and keeping aware. I couldn't even get the game to run on Steam. However, VTM-B has a very active, very devoted fanbase that creates custom content and mods so I was able to get a 'true to game' patch that simply made the game run in no time at all.

I only beat the game a few hours ago, but I am already thinking of second play throughs, with new mods and new choices. This game gives the player a ton of opportunities to alter the story, too. I felt like, at most every juncture, that my decisions mattered. That I wasn't just plodding through the developer's story but that I was writing a story of my own.

Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines manages to hold together a beautifully crafted environment, with some satisfying combat and evocative NPC interaction and story telling. It borders on perfection and a standard that other RPGs should be held to.

Pros:
+Amazing Atmosphere
+Cool and gothic without feeling forced
+Likeable/multidimensional NPCs
+Lots of choices and approaches to both build and story progression
+Satisfying, high-impact combat (at least in melee)
+Active fanbase producing extra content
+Very addictive once things get going

Cons:
-The first half hour or so of the game are slow and fail to grab attention
-The unmodded/unpatched game was not playable for me (but this is not such a big issue)
-Character building and numbers can be unintuitive

Overall, I would say it's completely worth the purchase, even at non-sale price.

reviewText:
Absolutely brilliant game in every aspect, this is my favorite horror RPG of all time! There is just so many options to choose from, both in development of your character’s personality and fighting style. You can basically play the game exactly the way you want the game to be played. I’ll recommend this game to everyone who likes a good dark and twisted RPG full of morbid and black humor.

As a newly embraced kindred you are given a lot of choices that could alter your overall storyline. If you believe in good or evil then your world might get turned around, as it all depends on point of view - your point of view. Will you seek allies to strengthen your fate or will you simply end up betraying them due to trust or individual differences?

An important condition for your new and eternal existence is your beast within and the craving for blood that follows. Going without blood when you’re thirsty will make your beast unsatisfied and release from the chains of you, till it once again will be filled and in slumber. This could break your most important rule - keep your identity hidden, keep your race a secret, respect the masquerade. Mortal curiosity could be your final death, if not by them then by your own, revealing the secrecy of your species is tolerated as betrayal as you will condemn the masquerade.

There is a lot of clans to choose from, even the choice of clan can alter the perspective people talk and greet you within the world. Every clan has unique armor and skill sets. All of the clans can choose the same stats depending on which role the player wish to play the game. Your stats affect your social and combat abilities.

Do you want to slice and dice or do you want to take your enemies out from a distance? You can choose your fighting style in combination with your clan’s skill set to create your own unique play style. However blood is limited so remember to feed when you can.

Your social abilities can help you to dominate, convince or seduce others to have your way. That can help you grant access to locations, free goodies or even a free blood snack!

Don’t forget to catch a squishy rattie when passing through the sewer. Why… one might ask…? Well… they’re deliciously tasty and uhm, ratties provide a fine amount of blood! Tasty, tasty ratties.

The game has only been improved by time, thanks to a great and active modding community and the unofficial patches, which I highly recommend to everyone who would like to play the game, as it fixes some of the game’s glitches and bug issues.

The game offers quality gameplay and storyline plus a huge amount of playtime and replay value.

reviewText:
Simply put, this is the best game I've ever played, and I've played tons of them over the span of 20+ years of gaming.

I'm a huge RPG fan. Easily my favorite genre. I've heard a lot about Bloodlines and people saying how great it was but I didn't get a chance to play it until recently. I'm so glad I finally played it because it is superb.

It's got an incredible, believable atmosphere of dread that draws you in completely and hooks you from the first minute of the game. It's got a great story with plenty of intrigue, interesting characters, some dark humor and excellent RPG systems under the hood that all come together to provide a fantastic gaming experience.

Your choices actually matter and different things will happen based on how you play the game. Unexpected outcomes can happen if you make the wrong" decision. The game always keeps you on your toes.

It's also got it's share of creepiness. You'll explore some levels that will scare you
date: and it also explores some dark and disturbing themes.\n\nAs I said at the beginning
recommended: it's the best game I've ever played. Highly recommended.\n\n10/10"
voteText: true

reviewText: I was recommended to play this game so many times. Being the idiot that judged a book by its cover, I often threw it aside and left it hanging there in my library. Sure enough, I sift through many old gems in the RPGs section, only to find it again, and again, and again. There must be a reason for an RPG to be great despite the technical difficulties and the outdated graphics, no? Sure enough I go for it (On my fifth attempt of liking it) and I was immediately pulled into its world and characters. This is the best example I would give to anyone asking for a high quality story experience, never mind the fact that it is a great RPG experience. I never played it at its time, but I sure have good memories of Vampire: The masquerade. I am normally not a pushover when it comes to games, but I would easily be one for anyone who is a big fan of RPGs and hasn't experienced such a masterpiece. I don't think I need to go into detail about it aside from the fact that it might turn away a lot of players due to its outdated presentation and technical limitations. Other than that, you can easily guarantee yourself a great game. Wherever you are LaCroix, thank you for showing me this.

reviewText: This is one of the games that simply enchant you with atmospere and world creation. The story is also great. This is no vampire love storry, and any of available characters would make Edward Cullen run home screaming for mommy. In here you are no prophecised demigod of vampires. You are a newcomer who doesn't know the world he/she's entering and everything around is dirty politics. You want to be a decent vampire? Sure, you'll be in control of the beast. You want to be a bloodsucking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ toying with his prey? You'll also be satisfied. You want to break the rules and kill humans on the street? Go on, but you'll be punished. If you can handle it, you're free to go.\nBut I guarantee the most fun aspect of the game is the role playing, the intrigue, the plot, and finding who (if anyone) is your true firnd at the end. This is a game depicting harsh, brutal, and dark world full of aristocrats, sycophants, celebrities, business moguls and simple junkies. What you do with it is your choice.\nThe only must have in case of this title is an extensive external mod bundle which will fix game's technical issues, enable it to run on newer Windows systems (runs great on my W8) and improve some graphics. But this game is worth this little trouble you'll have starting it up. Thanks to great community I'm going to enjoy it many years since now.

reviewText:
This dark, gritty, vulgar vampire game is something most people would expect to just be your typical game. This is something that kind of blew my mind. Just played an hour or so into it i noticed that it is very detailed in the types of vampires they have, the abilities, and the lifestyle. They do a very good job keeping everything shadey and making you play the game to discover more of it. You get to create how you want your character and it gives you a few options. Only thing is i noticed is it didn't have a character customization. What happens is theres a character thats pre-determined for each type of vampire. Suprisingly the graphics aren't that bad either. I figured they would be horrible or very dated due to it's time but for the game it still outshines most indie games these days.

I will update this further when i play more of the game, but for now i recommend this game.
Also if you purchase this game you might run into some issues running. All you need to do is patch the game and heres the link to it. Just simply place the patch into the steam file folder of the game and patch it up and enjoy!

Vampires: The Masquerade-Bloodlines 8.4 Patch

reviewText: VTMB is a wonderful RPG with amazing writing. Plenty of unexpected plot twists, even the ending surprised me. Lots of humor, which was always enjoyable too. The RPG elements were good, if a little confusing at first, the character sheet can be overwhelming at first glance, but it's easy to get the hang of eventually. VTMB provided you with plenty choices as well, involving not just the plot, but your style of gameplay, some of your dialogue, even extra areas depended on the clan you chose. The length of the game was also very nice, with loads of side quests in each area to do. The only downsides to this game were it's bugs, a lot of which were fixed in the unofficial patches, and the difficulty of some enemies seemed too hard at times, but with careful spending of experience points, lots of quicksaves, and patience, can be defeated easily enough. Overall, definitely one of my favorite games ever.

Now:
Probably the best overall writing ever seen in a video game. Deus Ex, Thief, Morrowind, System Shock and Pathologic were all excellent in their own respects --- but this game beats them all in terms of consistency and believability. Characters actually have personality, conversations actually flow, and every single NPC that can be interacted with has a ton of depth and maybe even a few ulterior motives. This game is easily tied with Deus Ex as the closest we've ever gotten to Warren Spector's one city block" vision. It simply has to be experienced to be believed.

reviewText:
A third-person action/RPG that is true to the old whitewolf roleplay system.

Pros:
- The game is true to the old pen and paper whitewolf system, you'll feel like you're really playing Vampire: The Masquerade
- Fun character generation with all the classic vampire clans complete with most of the old powers
- Immersive environments that make you feel like you're really in a vampire run city
- Intrigue and political tactics true to the setting complete with clan biases and alliances
- Interesting items and weapons that seem appropriate for the setting
- Different playstyles depending heavily on clan and powers
- Interesting quests that add a lot of color to the world
- A real feeling of power at higher level, but also danger as the game never becomes easy

Cons:
- Buggy, lots of crashes and locks can make things annoying at times
- Lots of prep work needed to get the game running, you usually have to use one of the fan-created patches to get this to work on steam
- Some knowledge needed, building a character poorly can make the game very hard to progress in

Overall:  This game is a great experience, even with the work needed to get it running (which is usually an instant fail for me), I have to recommend this game.  It's worth the investment to be able to immerse yourself in a game and a world that pays so much respect to the original Whitewolf source material.  And even if you've never played Vampire before, you can enjoy it for the interesting story and unique world.

reviewText: Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines is a simply sublime title by Troika. It was the third and final title they ever made before kicking the bucket.\n\nYou play as a newly formed vampire in a World of Darkness". You choose between several clans
date: from the rebellious Brujah to the insane Malkavians. Each clan has their own stat differences and NPCs react to you very differently. Especially if the player plays as a Nosferatu
recommended: you are treated like a hideous monster and cannot stay around human NPCs without them running away from you. The gameplay is solid and acts as both a first person shooter and a hack and slash.\n\nMost notable is the atmosphere of VtmB. It features very well made map design that is riddled with side quests in it's city hubs. Believe me when I say this game takes a while to complete
hoursPlayed: and is very rewarding once you do it. It is also replayable due to how much of the game changes depending on what clan you play as.\n\nIt runs on a beta version of the Source engine. The version it runs on is actually more primitive than Half Life 2. As a result the game is fairly buggy due to it's rushed development. However like all of Troika's games there is a large fan community that has released an unofficial patch that fixes most of the issues."

reviewText:
What to say about this game, man. First don't let the 1.1 hours mislead you, I've put around ten hours so far into this game. The Unofficial patch functions outside of steam so the counters not gonna work. I reccomend the patch by the way it has a list of improvements that make the game more enjoyable.

The Pro's:
-Lore. There's a lot of it and it is fairly easy to understand most of it.
-Graphics. Top notch for it's time, early 2000's, it has aged pretty well to my eyes.
-Audio/Voice Acting. The background music is pretty atmospheric and in tense situtions got my heart quickening a bit. The VO is well acted and cast, Each important and even supporting characters feel very distinct.
-Gameplay. It's an rpg so you'll have to manage stats and what not but I found keeping track of your Humanity" interesting as well as "The Masquerade". Falling to zero in either of those is game over. Also don't die

The Cons:
-Some small bugs are still present even with the patch but that's to be expected. Nothing is perfect.
-Character creation is really limited. You have about a dozen sub species of vampire to choose from but you CAN'T go in and edit facial appearances or anything. Options are limited to race

reviewText:
Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, is Role Playing game released in 2004. You can play in both First or Third-person Mode, as one of several vampire clans each with their own abilities and gameplay style: Playing as Nosferatu, are especially challenging. You start the game as a fledgling vampire who has to find your way through the streets of Los Angeles. Along the way you learn about the Various Vampire clans, as well as investigate a recently discovered relic that is supposed to bring an end to all vampires. The story takes you through Santa Monica, Downtown Los Angeles, Hollywood, Chinatown, as well as the Underground.

I don't want to go into the story to much, due to spoilers, but I will say the game has varying levels of difficult depending on what clan you choose to play as. You have the ability to create ghouls, which are humans who are fed Vampire blood, giving them powers, and binding the ghoul to you. I personally like the voice acting in this game and found some of the characters to be memorable such as; Jeanette. Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is a fun RPG, worth your time if you are into Occult-themed games.

reviewText:
First things first.  To deal with the game's issue with not being able to load properly, disable Steam updates and load the latest non-official patch.  After that, you're golden.

As far as good RPGs are concerned, I find myself returning to this game a lot.  I don't think I've ever had an RPG draw me into its world and characters as much as this one has, and the more I play it, the more I enjoy it.  It has its rough edges, mostly moments where combat is inevitable and odds feel stacked a bit unfairly against you.  Still, I love the ever living heck out of the interactions you have with characters, the dialogue, and the choices you can make thoughout the game.  Don't like the cop stopping you?  Mind control him, persuade him, seduce him.  There are plenty of choices and it's beautiful.

The game plays just long enough not to overstay its welcome.  Take the plunge and enter the World of Darkness.

reviewText:
This game is phenomenal, I don't usually use big words because it makes my head hurt but this time round I just had to bare with the pain in order to make this review. This game allows you to immerse yourself into a vampire role-playing game which is vast and has numerous twists, you start off as a nobody who is sired (turned) by someone you're sleeping with - male or female. Thus begins your story into the chaotic world of the supernatural, with numerous mods which change the story and add extra clans you'll be capable of sinking many hours into this game and gaining great pleasure from doing so. I don't usually make reviews unless the game is truly deserving of one, so let that bounce around your empty skull for a moment. You NEED to buy this game, you MUST have this game. Sorry, I just tried to dominate you - which is one of the many disciplines you are capable of having in this game. The game itself is known for having bugs, however the community keep making patches for it which fixes them and brings along new content.

10/10 - Carl Poppa Rating
You'll definitely need to buy this game if you are a fan of vampires, supernatural or are merely looking for an immersive role-playing game.

reviewText:
There is a reason this game still comes in on my Top 10 Favorite Games. At time of writing I have logged over 60 hours into this game. I love the setting, the gameplay, and the experiance that it presents to you.
The creatures and clans remain faithful to their source material which makes for a great mix of horror and RPG. Some of the creepier places really get under your skin. When this game came out, it had top of the line graphics, but has aged a bit. That doesn’t distract from the incredible art direction and level design.
With each clan bringing a unique playstyle, and 5 endings, this game has a lot of replayability. I especially enjoyed the madness inducing Malkavians. The game will often give you a goal and have several ways to accomplishing it. 10 years after the fact, I still love and play this game. Make sure you get the unofficial patch though. It fixes a lot of bugs and adds a lot of extra content (mainly stuff the designers hadn’t finished yet).

Overall, if your looking for a great game with horror/RPG elements, give this game a try. It will suck you into its world!

Highly Recommended

5/5

reviewText:
This is probably my favorite game ever created. I like this as much as Rappers like tax evasion(seriously guys do you taxes). I would even go as far as saying greatness and this game go together like Nicole Richie and calorie counters. The game allows you to make a character from 5 different clans. These clans all have thier own special abilities and feel really different. Oh yeah, I should mention that the game is very stat heavy. Now I am going to put down what I liked about the game in cliffnotes because current society's attention span is as short as Gary Coleman doing the crabwalk. Let us get into this,

What I liked?
-Very stat heavy which makes for some interesting skillchecks
-Multiple ways to create a character
-Multiple ways to complete a mission
-Brilliant Dialogue(If you want movie type of dialogue this is the game if you want book type of dialogue look for Planetscape : Torment)
-Voice acting is spot on, probably one of the best voice acting ever recorded in an rpg.
-Combat abilities are just marvelous
-Clan specific abilities give your character a different feel.
-Lots of Side Missions
-Interesting story component
-Multiple Endings
-Mixture of Minor and Major Decisions to be made(Not all rpgs should be based on making decisions of finding a cure for cancer or ending world hunger)

What I didn't like?
-BUGS. With the amount of bugs that this game has, you would think it was made by an obsidian programmer working through a hangover. The amount of bugs in this game are probably being cast for ANTZ 2(3?). When I think about the bugs i run away in peril because I think they are all over me. (They are amazing patches to fix this though)
-The last quarter of the game was more copy paste than that friend of yours that leaves assignments till sunday. Seriously troika fix your ♥♥♥♥.

Other than that it is probably my most favorite game out there. I would go ahead and give it what it is due. VTMB with patches and everything is a complete 9.7/10. I absolutely wasted and had so much fun in this game. I would recommend it for anyone that wants to have fun. Seriously get it.

DISCLAIMER : IDONTWORKFORACTIVISIONANDMYENDORSEMENTOFTHISPROJECTDOESNOTMEANIAMGETTINGPAYEDFORITSOWHYDONTYOUHOPOFFANDLETMEFINISHWRITINGTHISREVIEWBEFOREISETITOFFINTHISPLACECAUSEYOUDONOTKNOWMELIKETHAT...SIR.

Good day

reviewText: This game is so good that you even forget that this is an old game (with its related limitations). It perfectly represents the punk gothic scenario designed for the Storyteller’s RPG, putting all the environmental, climate, and situations exactly as it should be in such world - a must for those who used to play the RPG. The history is very interesting and the dialogues are well written and very funny several times. Even the advertisement that plays on the radio (which you can ignore if you want) is funny and well elaborated. The haunted house mission is a memorable moment of the game and is a good example of how this game is well made. In overall, any fan of the genre will have a lot of fun playing it and I definitely recommend it.\nAs a con, the necessity of having to use an external patch from a third party in order to get the best performance of the game is something bad as you expect to purchase a perfect version. However, the forum is really helpful to guide the player through this process and it worked fine for me. Sometimes the game got buggy, but nothing that harassed the gameplay.

reviewText: This has been my favorite game since it released in '04. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes the supernatural (vampires, werewolves, ghosts, etc.), dark humor, and an RPG more akin to Deus Ex than Oblivion. For additional enjoyment, get the Unofficial Patch, which you can easily find via Google. It is still being updated from time to time by a talented devotee who goes by Wesp5. The patch features a basic version that fixes any bugs that have been brought to light and can be corrected, as well as a plus version which includes actual content that was in the game but had not been implemented at the time of release; even pre-recorded dialog and weaponry. I've beaten the game somewhere between 20 and 30 times, you can play as 7 different types of vampire, each of which you can upgrade differently with experience points, which are gained via completing quests rather than grinding kills.

reviewText: NOTE: It says I have zero game hours because I used the unofficial patch and it didn't record my Steam hours. Just know that I played this game ALOT.\n\nThis is my second favorite role-playing game of all time! And it's still extremely close to my first favorite, Mass Effect 2. The voice acting is really, really good. You get a pen and paper-like character customizer where you get to pick your gender, and vampire clan along with a backstory about before you became a vampire. The intro is really interesting and builds the world very well. You really do feel like a vampire that's hiding their true identity in Los Angeles. Each quest is interesting, and are all worth playing. Instead of an open world, you get four hub cities Santa Monica, Hollywood, Downtown, and Chinatown. Depending on your gender, clan, and certain skills, you can select alot of interesting dialogue options, and unlock more too! The lore is very interesting, and I recommend studying it on the White Wolf Wiki if you're gonna buy this game. This game also has great characters who are all very detailed in the world. In fact, my favorite gaming character of all time came from this game, Therese Voerman. If you look past the dated graphics, even some bugs with the unofficial patch still installed, and look at all the great things this game has to offer like detailed role-playing, interesting characters, a well set up world, rich lore, and great quests, you can easily have alot of fun with this game.

reviewText: First off let me say this, i have played this game for many, many hours back in the day when it was on CD-ROM, do not judge the play hours i have on this from steam. The game's depth is incredible considering it was a rushed game back in 2004 and one of the first Source games made. The soundtrack is nothing short of superb and fits almost every mood in the game as well. I could go on and on about every aspect of the game but if i were then you would go into the game knowing what to expect. Just look at the amount of positive reviews  the game has and take that as a good sign, especially considering that practically all of the negative reviews is due to people not using the unofficial patch and fixing all of the games problems, like i said it was a rushed game, but the fact that a rushed game is still one of the best experiences i have ever had in the past 11 years in  a game says quite a'lot.

reviewText:
Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines is a rare gem. It takes the basic gameplay of the intelligent shooters of old and mixes it with a heavy does of RPG mechanics and open ended storytelling.

Bloodlines start you off in a very classic vampire way, you find yourself in a seedy motel room being hot and heavy with someone of the opposite sex when all of the sudden they bite you. Before you get a chance to get your bearings some goons storm the place and take you and your new lover away to a court where your lover is executed for making a new vampire without permission but you are uncharacteristically spared. You are then set loose on the streets where a friendly old geezer explains what it means to be a vampire and after a quick tutorial introducing you the various concepts of the game you are free to explore the city.

Bloodlines is a first person shooter in it's most basic form although many of the weapons and abilities are melee in nature. It takes a great deal of inspiration from Deus Ex and System Shock by creating a myriad of different ways to go about each area. Lots of vents and back alleys, locks to pick and people to persuade. There is always another way to go about things depending on your skills and inclination. The RPG system is fairly straight forward, you get skill points as you level up which can then be put into a myriad of different skills and abilities including some special vampire magic that tends to be specific to the vampire clan you select during character creation.

The vampire clans are on the big highlights of the game with the most notable mentions being Nosferatu who are hideous and unable to pass for a human unlike the other clans and the the Malkavians who are, quite literally, completely and utterly insane. Both of these change the way you play and experience the game significantly and in particular the Malkavian guarantees you will need a second playthrough.

The main storyline isn't anything tremendously exciting however the smaller side-quests and the world itself is exceptionally well written and acted and you will feel heavily immersed throughout the game.

Source is the engine upon which this is all created which makes for a decent looking game even though it was released a good while after Half-Life 2 due to licensing issues which unfortunately also had the side-effect of absolutely killing the sales of this game and also Troika, the developers.

When originally released Bloodlines was extremely bug ridden despite the delay in release and it was nearly unplayable at that point, now however most of the bugs have been patched out and for those few things left unfinished there is a very high quality fan made patch that I recommend everyone gets before playing the game.

All in all Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines is one of the best games of the modern era and one of the few modern games that manages to pull off a first person view without losing sight of what the game is trying to accomplish. You could classify it as an action RPG or as a first person shooter with some RPG elements but either way, it's a great game.
