reviewText:
Rating: 8.5/10

What is it?
First Person RPG in a vampire setting.

The Good:

+ Character creation is excellent. You start off by choosing your vampire clan. Each clan has its own set of abilities. Two clans in particular really change the game up: The Malkavians and the nosferatu really play differently from the other clans offering some nice replay value.

+ Lots of stats to further build your character. Play as a melee, stealth, guns, hacking etc.  Build a character that fits your play style

+ The plot and characters are interesting, they really flesh out the story and dialogue.

+ Great main and side missions

+ Multiple ways of completing your missions depending on your character build. Go in guns blazing, or sneak in through the back, etc.

+ A lengthy game that never feels boring or drawn out simply because the developers did a good job of keeping things interesting all the way through.

The Bad:

- Technical and texture glitches. The game was officially patched however there were still plenty of bugs left over. You must play with some of the unofficial patches. I was playing with a widescreen mod which may have contributed to all the texture anomalies.

-The combat feels less polished then the rest of the game. Melee combat goes into third person view which could be off putting to some. Using guns can be very frustrating and probably won't be worth it until you invest some heavy experience points into the firearm skill. Guns probably won't be effective until half way through the game.

- Some really annoying parts of the game.  Luckily it was far and few between to really hurt the overall experience.

Conclusion

A great game, and if you love RPG's this is a great game that you can't go wrong with. Possibly one of the best vampire games out there.

reviewText:
I'm not normally a fan of Vampire games, but I picked up this one upon recommendation by a friend, and holy cow is it good! Important points include:
1) There are violent encounters you can turn into diplomatic ones, if you're very diplomatic.
2) There are stealth encounters you can turn into shoot 'em up encounters, if you're inclined.
3) The game is reasonably faithful to the tabletop, but makes some pretty clear changes to make it a good video game.
4) There's a mission where you're supposed to get rid of a ghost. It just might be the scariest mission in the whole game, and you don't fight a single monster or enemy the whole time.
5) If you play the game as a Malkavian, your flaw is that you're crazy. So they changed all the dialogue options to reflect this, voiced over responses to your crazy talk, and made a few other changes to make it really work.
6) This is the first time since high school that I felt like I really wanted to play a vampire tabletop game.

NOTE: The unofficial patch (now in version 9.0) is basically required to play this game on a modern computer. You can get it here: http://www.patches-scrolls.com/vampire_bloodlines.php

reviewText:
One of the greatest FPSRPG games of all time, thwarted by it's own ambitious design, a publisher that refused to allocate funds to finish and polish the game, and valve cockblocking the release until half life 2 was out (which of course stole all the limelight and caused the game to sell poorly)

It has since developed a cult following, and numerous unnofficial patches and gameplay updates.

It really succeeds in making you feel like an undead badass and in portraying a world that thrives at 3am, features memorable locations like a gothic nightclub, a hollywood porno store and of course a haunted house (and theatre, and cemetary, and derelict hospital, and rundown apartment building, and fish market.... basically there's a lot of hauntings)

Features some terrific writing, dialogue and humour. It also has a great levelling system where allocated skills and abilities actually affect the gameplay in a big way.

Gamebreaking bugs and glitches can usually be overcome with the unnofficial patches, and are highly recommended.

reviewText:
It should be noted straight away that this game cannot be run on modern operating systems without unofficial patches. For those who don't want to take the time to figure out how to do this, you'll probably want to avoid purchasing this game.

That said, if you're comfortable with spending a few minutes finding and installing the unofficial patches, you might find this game interesting. You should probably wait for a deep-cut sale though; $20 for a 10 year old game that barely made it out of production is a little silly.

The good:
- Excellent writing (easily the best aspect of the game)
- Compelling storyline
- Interesting lore and characters
- Voice acting is very well done
- Play as one of seven vampire clans with differing abilities
- Allows for several different play styles
- Explore side quests in a non-linear fashion
- Multiple endings

The bad:
- Combat feels very clumsy. The defensive stance in melee combat is essentially worthless. It is difficult to maneuver and avoid being hit by enemy attacks.
- The game favors melee combat until much later in the game where guns are very powerful. However, since this is an RPG, the player must level up their skills one way or the other. Certain boss encounters are very difficult for players who choose a melee play style.
- There are stats that are basically worthless to invest in, such as haggling. Lockpicking and hacking can be useful for those in a hurry, but are in most cases not needed since keys and password notes can be found nearby. Other stats such as those used to influence others in dialogue are useful early on in the game, but aren't used at all later on.
- It is not possible to remain in first-person view at all times. The game forces you into the third-person view when engaging in melee combat. Ranged combat functions like a first person shooter.
- The player can make many different choices, but there are no diverging story paths. All choices the player makes eventually lead to the same outcome.
- The graphics aren't terrible, but look quite dated.
- At times there are graphical glitches or weird physics.

reviewText: One of the most immersive and unique RPGs you will ever find. Imagine if you take the action, skills, moral choises and decisions from games like Deus Ex and Fallout 3, and combine that aspect with a modern world secret vampire society set in the midst of Hollywood - Los Angeles. Then you have the recipe that is Vamire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.\n\nAs a newly turned vampire you are off to a rocky start. You begin to unravel ancient mysteries and conspiracies within the society itself. Many clans are at war with eachother, and it's up to you to decide which sides to take. You can either try to resolve things through diplomatic efforts to stay in touch with your human side as much as possible, or go the more animalistic way of violence and murder. But beware, everything you do may have serious consequences!

reviewText:
Well, where to start with this game. It is easy to be swallowed in to the game by it's rich storyline and a fantasticly written dialogue - but it's not just that. I felt immersed in this game that was able to describe and not only give me an idea of - but also allow me to feel like I was suddenly pulled into a vampire society. Which, judging by the popularity of the vampire genre in video gaming, seems to be something that many games involving vampires have great difficulty with.
I look forward to the future and hope that the vampire genre can be inspired by this game.

I'll list the pros and cons of this briefly, from my experience.

Pros:
~ Deep and non-linear storyline.
~ At the start, you can choose your stats or 'roll' them randomly (let the game decide!), and have a choice of clans with their own personality, background, advantages and disadvantages.
~ Creative and well written dialogue, of which can change depending on chosen clan.
~ Voice acting that fits well with the characters and enriches their personalities.
~ Many hours of play filled with many missions and many choices for you to make.
~ Experience various entertaining kinds of insanity.

Cons:
~ There are bugs. The patch does help with this and is easy to find with a web search. However, it does not eliminate them completely, and this is also to be expected when playing an old game. Personally I wasn't bothered by them, as I was too busy enjoying the storyline.
~ Combat is funky. This links with the bugs, but don't get me wrong - there are tough fights.
~ Graphics can be improved with the patch I believe, but are still old. It's not disasterous or unplayable however, by any means - on the contrary, very good for an old game in my opinion.
~ For some people this will be a con. SAVE OFTEN. Your experience of the game will differ in places depending on the choices you make, and you may want to go back to have a different experience later. And then of course, there's always the possibility of getting shredded up and dying.

reviewText: So long as you install the unofficial patch before you try it, this is an awesome game, and surprisingly engaging considering its age. Sure the graphics are pretty bad, and the voice acting is somewhat static-y, but the characters feel real, and there's tons to explore. Even once the game's been completed, there's more to do, from extremely in-depth mods, to entirely different playstyle choices. I've just finished playing Vampire: The Masquerade for almost 4 days straight; personally, I haven't begun to get tired of it yet, and not one ounce of that is nostagia.

reviewText:
Vampire the Masquerade - Bloodlines, i remember getting this game back in 2004... back then i was really disappointed  from the lack of MP, but at least you get to meet with Werewolves, Wraiths, Kueijins and all sorts of Lore Creatures of the Night from World of Darkness.


THE GOOD:

The Graphics
The Story
Loyal to WhiteWolf World of Darkness
Hair and Cloth Physics from a 2004 game (seriously, there are modern games who lack this... Cough*Skyrim*Cough)
Nice Levels such as the Haunted Hotel, Griffin Park, Giovanni Mansion

THE BAD:

No Multi Player
Repetitive  Combat
Bad Weapon Aim and Ridiculous Fire Recoil which makes some Weapons useless
Long Loading Times

Overall is a good game, but i prefer Vampire The Masquerade - Redemption over Bloodlines for one simple reason, StoryTeller mode and Multiplayer.

My Score for this game is 8 out of 10

reviewText: Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, is a near perfect gaming experience despite coming across hundreds of flaws in most every aspect of the game, from the visuals, audio, optimization, rushed mechanics, poor save files, and so forth... Bloodlines suffers from a plagued development, and is far from finished, but comes across as a product both greatly entertaining and lengthy in gameplay. Utilizing the HL2 Source engine, Bloodlines is easily modifiable, and as such many fan made community patches are in circulation around the internet. I highly recommend downloading these patches for a more refined and polished gaming experience (although it is optional as the game is still playable all the way through without said patches). Bloodlines delivers exceptional voice acting, a grim and atmospheric setting, a fantastically agreeable soundtrack, a fair amount of character customization, and at times, a fair amount of role-playing choices, all for a low sum of 20 bucks, and believe me folks - with said amount of issues, it's still very much worth it.

reviewText:
This is a great older RPG with a dark atmosphere and interesting background lore.

You don't just deal with vampires. Just a few things you do are investigate a haunted house, rummage through a serial killers' abode, and make your way through an abandoned hospital to discover what has been dragging people to the basement. There are also numerous moral choices in the game and multiple endings.

The game offers major replayability due the numerous possibilities through clan selection. Although, I reccommend not doing the Malkavian clan or the Nosferatu until your second playthrough given how much they alter the game.

reviewText:
Ok yeah so the game is old. And it shows. And it's pretty janky and buggy and needs a bit of patching to run smoothly (crash to desktop on boot, anyone?) BUT...

Seriously, if you enjoy RPG action games, PLEASE give this one a try. The story is brilliant, and it features one of the best spooky levels/missions I've ever experienced in a videogame. It's pretty authentic to the hard-copy pen and paper (and LARP) RPG system which it is based on, so if you're a fan of the tabletop/larp, you should get a kick out of this!

It's a little treasure of a game, beloved by its fans, and honestly if you can look past the dated appearance (I personally find it rather charming) and deal with the occasional bugs (seriously, PLEASE check the forums for this game if you pick it up and download the unofficial patch) you should have a pretty good time.

Also vampires. :)

reviewText:
Once upon a time there existed video games which did not require endless grinding or other players to be fun.
Remember before MMO and survival games came into existence?  When you paid for your game up front, with no forking out for DLC or micropayments?  Remember that wonderful thing called an imagination?  You know that thing with which, when you hear a story, your mind constructs an image?
If not, you had best get back to Destiny in case you miss out on a fun grinding festival (THIS WEEK ONLY).

On the other hand, if you miss the old days when you were immersed in the plot of a game without there ever being a monetary catch, take heed.
This game invites you into the World of Darkness (WoD) and sets you on a bloody path through vampire society's political intrigue and betrayal.  Imagine a world not unlike our own filled with all manner of supernatural beasts; from vampires to werewolves and demons, WoD has it all.
Choose Nosferatu and work your way through missions carefully, transiting via the sewers and using vampiric powers to hide your hideous form from the human population.  Feed your inner beast as Gangrel, slaughtering all opposition with deadly claws and inhuman strength.  Or you could charm your way through machination after machination as Toreador or Ventrue.  And so on.
On top of this, the semi-linear storyline is enhanced with the faction system.  Choose which side you wish to support - the Brujah and their Anarchists or the Ventrue and their Camarilla.  The possibilities in gameplay will keep you entertained for hours.

Overall, I'd give the game 85%...owing to its age and minor bugs.

The WoD managed to make vampires cool without turning them into spoilt brats and people seemingly damned to an eternity as angsty teens (a la True Blood/ Twishite) so you should check it out if you're into that sort of thing!
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is amazing.  I actually stood around a radio in this game just to listen to each radio program loop in each game chapter because it was so damn entertaining.  This game is loaded with so much awesome stuff, and the humor in it is great.  It's a shame these guys when out of business, they had the potential to make games as good as anything Bethesda has put out.

A note about all the people complaining about this game needing a patch to run: Of course it does, morons, stop your whining.  This game was made to run on an operating system that's been obsolete for over a decade (and people could argue that Windows ME/2000/XP/etc were garbage when they came out), and the company that made the game was crushed and is long gone, of course you will need to DL a patch to run it.  The good news is that these patches also fix bugs that were originally issues in the game.  So look up and follow the easy to install patches, it's totally worth it (and they are free, so ... yeah).

This game is also worth multiple play-throughs, which can be hard to find with linear story/plot games.  As each clan (and gender) has some different perks, playing through more than once can be rewarding.  And if you haven't played as a Malkavian (the crazy ones), that is always good for a last play-through for the whole game.

Great for any fan of Vampire the Masquerade, great for any vampire genre fan, great for any FP/RPG game lover.
I played this a LONG time ago, and playing again now is just as fun, and it is still an impressive game.  I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
“Remember, wherever we go, it is the blood of Caine which makes our fate.”

Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines is a great role-playing game with an immersive dark atmosphere, authentic characters and a solid storyline, that does the game justice. The bloodline (clan) you choose will affect your relationship with other characters, the available quests and the choices presented to you throughout the game, offering plenty of variation and replayability.
While the A.I. is simple and pretty straight forward, the game often gives you several ways to solve a situation, including combat, stealth and rhetorical possibilities. The unbalanced combat mechanics are the weakest link of the game, which can create partially frustrating combat situations.

The official support for this game was stopped in 2005, leaving it behind with numerous bugs. The fan community has released an unofficial patch, which addresses most of the issues and can be found on the link below (thanks to Voxel).

http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647

To fix the runtime error, try the following link (thanks to Zzero).

http://steamcommunity.com/app/2400/discussions/3/846959521009517711/

Fun Fact: The several different vampire clans and their various strengths and weaknesses are based on the tabletop role-playing franchise Vampire: The Masquerade.
--

My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:

-	Atmosphere
-	Characters
-	Details
-	Tactical gameplay
-	Story
-	Combat & Controls

Based on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading:

-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

If the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).
--

Atmosphere: S-Rank

(Ah, your’re gonna love this! Alright, check it out. Blood: It’s your new rack o’lamb, your new champagne – blood’s your new ♥♥♥♥in’ heroin, kid.)

Characters: S-Rank

(I am the proprietor and salesman of the month several years in a row; the ladies call me “Oh, god!”, but you can call me Fat Larry with F-A-T, ‘cause I know I got a weight problem and I just don’t give a ♥♥♥♥.)

Details: S-Rank

(Man, we got everything you’ll ever need. Softcore, hardcore, gay, straight, farm or furry. We got shockers, shiverers, self-lubricators and strap-ons. Chains, crops and canes are in the back next to the triple-ripple. Like I said, we got it all.)

Tactical gameplay: A-Rank

Story: B-Rank

Combat & Controls: C-Rank
--

There are no achievements to conquer.

Achievement difficulty: none
--

(Dark Fantasy) – 2004

reviewText:
Pros:
Fantastic Storytelling, perhaps the game's strongest element.
Plenty of options for characters: Strong, Charismatic, Deadly; however you'd like to play, there's a way to do it.
A plethora of memorable characters, backed with Excellent voice acting.
An engaging plot, with plenty of sidequests: At least 30 hours of content.
Unique character development that adheres to White Wolf's game system.
Cons:
Combat is sketchy. Those looking for a beat-em-up or a FPS will be dissapointed.
The endgame involves a lot of combat, and may be dissapointing for relatively pacifist players. Also, see above.
The out of box product is rather buggy, and even the official patched and plus patched versions can have memory leak issues. Save early, and save often.

If you get this game (and you should, believe me) Be sure to install either the unofficial patch, which fixes a lot of inherent issues with the game, or the plus patch, which restores deleted content and improves existing content for smoother gameplay. As is, the game includes the 1.2 official patch

Patch 9.2 [forums.planetvampire.com]

Being one of the finest RPGs out there in the sense that it adheres to Role-Playing,  Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines  Is a must for anyone who considers themselves a fan of RPGs. It has its flaws, yes, but it's a shining example of what interactive roleplaying can and should look like.

TL;DR I give it 9/10. Install the unofficial patch.

reviewText: If this game had more time for polishing (*cough* thanks a lot Activision *cough*), it would have easily been the best RPG. The combat is mediocre at best, but on the other hand, the dialogue, characters and story are great. The class system also adds a lot of replayability too, thanks to how different each gameplay can be depending on what kind of vampire you picked.\n\nDon't expect to play the game without any issues though. Even with the community's unofficial patches, I still encountered multiple major bugs (bosses went through the level, quests couldn't be completed, characters not appearing when they are supposed to and so on). But still, it's definitely worth playing.

reviewText:
Seriously, the writing in this game is among the best in the world of video games so far. Not only is the gameplay fantastic and the story excellent, but the writing, God, the WRITING. The dialogues are amazing, and after you've played through as whatever non-Malkavian clan you chose, you need to play it again as Malkavian for more hilarious dialogue.

Oh and don't let my recorded play time fool you, as I own this game retail, and played it a lot before I re-bought on Steam for convenience. It's seriously one of my favorite games of all time, and as far as WRPG goes it up there with Deus Ex and other classics you just get that occasional hankering for.

Just, just play it, and then despair as you realize lesser games aren't as fun anymore.

reviewText:
This game is such a delight to anyone a fan of horror and vampires, the attention to detail of gameplay and storyline for a game of the day and age for once it came out is of a unique high quality.

The ability to turn from first person shooter to 3rd person at a moments notice for play style makes it versatile and keeps it fresh, full spoken dialog from characters in the world and questlines, the ability to choose and customize yourself/character from a variety of talents to apply to the game to finish objectives, play styles have a wide variety (be a sneaky lockpicking/hacker, a monster of a vampire with a brutish thirsts for blood and chaos, or a socialite with a sharp tongue for manipulation etc etc!). This aspect makes this game very re-playable, if one would like to explore all aspects that the game can offer.

The character creation also gives you a variety of vampire clans to choose from, each with their own personal look and place within the world; special attacks and specializations are given for each clan presented depending on which one you choose from, some clans provide abilities that will help cater to the play style that you would wish to use.

The beauty of this game is that they're more than one solution to finish a job and it purely depends on how you want to play the game and how you spread out your talent system. I don't want to give too much away but I highly recommend this game!

I also recommend that before you play the game that you download the unofficial patch for the game as it removes some of the ingame bugs. http://www.moddb.com/mods/vtmb-unofficial-patch

The link also has a few cool mods to add onto the game like the Final Nights mod that changes the selection of clans in the character creation menu with all new special abilities and all that good stuff (do this after you play the origianls clans/clan if you are looking for more fun!)

It's probably a very short review compared to the grand scale of this game has to offer but I hope I helped someone in convincing them to play this great game :D

reviewText: One of the most underrated games in gaming history. It's a flawed gem of a game, but the unofficial patches clean the game up really nicely. It has an incredibly interesting story, amazing atmosphere, and some really memorable quests and dialogs. The combat and stealth systems are clunky, but a great effort has been made via the unofficial patches to improve these aspects, and it now works a lot better than before the patches.\n\nIn summary, if you're up for an RPG with a dark setting, memorable characters, and an amazing world filled with tons of interesting lore, then look no further than this game.

reviewText:
This is what I call a good electronic RPG.
Not only because you can build and evolve your character, but more importantly:
- story is good and makes sense,
- nice atmosphere,
- your choices do make difference (without the usual need to play the good boy to get more rewards)
- your character's clan and stats define which options you have on dialogues (Malkavian dialogues are awesome! Specially if you have Dementia power...)

If you like the pen-and-paper Vampire: The Masquerade you'll probably enjoy this game. It is a very nice implementation of the World of Darkness, and you know, vampires aren't the only supernatural creatures in the night...

Only three issues bothered me (but were not enough to make me quit playing):
1- streets sometimes feel too empty, but than you remember you're a vampire and it's probably late at night! Also you'll probably be thankful for that, after all, you don't really want people discovering you're a vampire all the time ;-)
2- you need to install an unofficial patch (at least on my Win7 64 bits, the game was broken without the patch)
3- for those used to the pen-and-paper Vampire, some of the disciplines were replaced by new ones due to limitations of a PC game, but they are still nice;

I really recommend this one!

reviewText:
When I first started to play this game I didn't really expect much out of it, truth be told. It had earned a rather nasty reputation over the years but it was on sale and I decided to try it out. It was a decision I would not regret.

Graphics 5/10 - The graphics in this game have not aged well to say the least but don't let that discourage you. If you can look past the dated appearance of the game you will find plenty to enjoy.

Sound 9/10 - The sound design in this game is fantastic. Although the sound effects can lack impact at times, the soundtrack really sets the mood for the world of darkness. More then once I found my heart racing in anticipation over what would be around the next corner. Play the haunted house level in this game and you will know what I mean (very atmospheric!).

Level Design 7/10 - With the exception of the games main huds, the levels in this game are all pretty linear. It would have been nice if the game gave more alternate routes to your destinations, Deus Ex style. It does indeed do that at times if you keep an eye open for them (or your investigate skill is high enough) but such events are few and far between. Despite this though, I never felt bored on my first playthrough.

Story 9/10 - The story in the game is masterfully woven. I found myself constantly thinking about who I should trust and distrust. In one case you can discover a potential allies true motivations before the end of the game and tell them to go to hell but with the others you have to take a leap of faith and hope your instincts are on the ball. This adds a level of uncertainty to your actions as you feel more and more like a diposable pawn with no will of your own, surrounded by master manipulators who wish to use your skills for their own gain and then toss you aside like yesterdays news.

Quests 10/10 - The quests in this game really shine. Investigate and evil cult, track down a supernatural serial killer or take down a group of famous vampire hunters. This game really keeps your interest by giving you well written quests that are not only entertaining, but also give you the feeling that you are making this dark world a better place with each step you take.

Bugs Presence 2/10 - When this game was released it had a ton of bugs since Activision rushed it to market. However, there is an unofficial patch for this game - which is still being updated - that removes nearly all of these issues and then some. It also adds plenty of new content into the game so I would HIGHLY recommend it. In fact, I've heard it's pretty much essential since this game can't run really well on modern operating systems without it, which makes perfect sense given the games age. There are still some minor bugs present, sometimes I would have difficulty climbing a certain set of stairs or would partially clipp through a wall but these instances are minor and quite rare so they were never an impediment for me.

All in all, this game is worth a purchase. I've played through it several times with different clans and enjoyed it every single time. At only 20 bucks you certainly can't go wrong. Hopefully, someday we will get a sequel to this game, with all the potential on display I can only hope for a sequel. The MMO was a bust but I will remain hopeful for the future of this franchise.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games of not just the RPG genre but of any genre. Be warned right now though you will want a unoffical patch as Troika Games is no longer around and it does have some bugs. Also when it says mature 17+ it means it.

You play the role of a fledgling vampire from the world of whitewolf. Its a dark and gritty world where their are no good guys, just different degrees of evil ones. You will choose from one of seven differnt clans (clans are differnt bloodlines of vampires each with their own quirks and perks) that lead to a very differnt type of game on multiple play threws.

Combat is not the smoothest and the graphics are a bit dated. However the voice acting is superb the atmosphere is a increadible 11/10 as well. Depending on how you spend your EXP points on various skill and what type of vampire clan you are the base game can play very differntly from one play threw to another. Also features a 5 ending setup (although some endings arnt as varied as what you would think) leaving the game open to some replayability even at the ending.

Overall i would give this game a 10/10 even with its problems and age.

reviewText: This game is an amazing adventure through the old World of Darkness, suitable for anyone regardless of experience with the tabletop roleplaying game. For those interested in that, I'd like to note the world in which this game takes place has been rebooted in a new game, and the current analogue to Vampire: The Masquerade is called Vampire: The Requiem. Some terms and ideas still exist, but the very feel of the world and the themes of the game are wholly different. They've switched from the advertised gothic-punk" atmosphere (a term the company itself uses to describe the old setting) to a more supernatural mystery/thriller feel.\n\nEven if you don't intend to play the tabletop game
date: this is still one of my favorite RPGs
recommended: period. Just make sure you go out and download the unofficial patch collection from a mod website. It's still buggy as hell."

reviewText:
I love this game. I played it back when it first came out in 2004. It is now several years old but has held up very well.

In the game you start out with a somewhat lengthy cutscene which gives you an idea of the society you now belong to as a new vampire or childe. You are then released into a somewhat open world to begin your undead life as pretty much everyone's errand person. Your style of play will obviously depend on what clan you chose at the beginning. Whether you are a fighting brujah, beastly gangrel, squishy tremere, smooth toreador, snooty ventrue, crazy malkavian, or *shudders* disgusting nosferatu; you will find plenty to fight in the perpetual darkness.

This game has decent graphics (especially considering its age), great dialogue, believeable characters (and some pretty wild ones too), monsters (other than vampires), plenty of seduction, AWESOME music (seriously though... this game introduced me to several artists that I had never heard of that I still listen to til ths day), and an overall decent and interesting story. One word of advice... explore the cities and talk to everyone... multiple times. There are many interesting side quests that you can easily miss!

It has a few glitches that can sometimes occur in unpatched versions. Only thing I dislike about this game is how many autoaves it produces. It creates a new autosave every time instead of simply rewriting the autosave file. This feature cannot be turned off as far as I am aware. Periodically you will need to go through and clean up the older autosaves.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games of not just the RPG genre but of any genre. Be warned right now though you will want a unoffical patch as Troika Games is no longer around and it does have some bugs. Also when it says mature 17+ it means it.

You play the role of a fledgling vampire from the world of whitewolf. Its a dark and gritty world where their are no good guys, just different degrees of evil ones. You will choose from one of seven differnt clans (clans are differnt bloodlines of vampires each with their own quirks and perks) that lead to a very differnt type of game on multiple play threws.

Combat is not the smoothest and the graphics are a bit dated. However the voice acting is superb the atmosphere is a increadible 11/10 as well. Depending on how you spend your EXP points on various skill and what type of vampire clan you are the base game can play very differntly from one play threw to another. Also features a 5 ending setup (although some endings arnt as varied as what you would think) leaving the game open to some replayability even at the ending.

Overall i would give this game a 10/10 even with its problems and age.

reviewText:
It was a bit tough to get this game started because I didn't have at least 15mb of RAM, but after installing the unofficial 9.2 patch, the game ran like a charm. I think during the entire play through I had less than half a dozen crashes. I found this to be pretty impressive considering I couldn't even launch the game after installation.

Ok, so if you've bought the game and installed the 9.2 patch, the next step is to mod your female character to look like Jeanette or Velvet Velour ;)

On to the game!
Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines sounds like a sequel and there was a game before it, but it starts fresh and doesn't seem to carry any baggage from the previous game. You play with roleplaying-style skill points which increase as you buy into the higher levels. Your skills range from melee, to stealth, to guns, to computer hacking, and everything in between!

When creating your character you choose between male and female, and then one of many different families. These families give you your vampire powers, like terrifying presence, or moving in super speed.

Your job as a newly converted vampire is to do the will of your Prince and leader. During your missions you'll meet so many creative and unique characters. The world you're put into is just so unique and enjoyable from everything else out there right now, it's really hard to describe how this game's story was.

Bottom Line: Get this game. If you like great stories and/or role-playing games, then this is a gem I had missed for years and I wouldn't want any of you to miss it any longer.

reviewText:
I would like to note that before anyone buys this, it will NOT RUN on modern machines unless you install fanmade patches. ( http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2025035 )

In this day and age vampires are often a mockery in pop culture, thanks in large part to sensations like Twilight. But let me tell you, this game has no glittering pretty boys. It's a true painting of what the modern vampire should be- they walk among us in society because they look like us, often using their intelligence and sex appeal to feed and maintain their powers. The game largely focuses on the politics within vampire society known as The Masquerade- it's this web of politics that sends you off on several quests where, depending on how you've chosen to level your character and converse in dialogue with NPCs can play out very differently.
The side quests are also very compelling. And I'm usually incredibly disinterested in these- the lore and the characters are all just so well written it made me want to explore the game more.

If you're looking for an obscure gem, excellent writing, unique atmosphere, or just tired of seeing Vampires suck ♥♥♥ like they have been in recent years this game is up your alley.

reviewText: Do not betray the Masquerade, Kindred, for the penalties of alerting humanity to our presence is dire indeed. Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines is an RPG powerhouse. reviewText:
First of all, look at my total hours of playing this game...I know its zero(now probably just a few hours)...thats because I got the game back in 2004 when it came out and now with the steam platform I just had to get it here. With that said, let me tell you, I installed this game in 2004 and still have it installed today in 2014, I have well over 500 hours on this game and I will now proceed to try and give it another 500 hours on steam and heres why!

This is my favourite game, I fell in love with it the second I played it.
Its a very dark game that shows you the real world behind our lives and the sugar cotted world where we live in.
You will see that this World of Darkness thats all around us Humans, is a brutal world where sex, violence and murder along with a lot more sins are casual things on a normal night in the vampire society.

The gameplay is pretty much summed up as a quest based RPG, you have your main quest line but if you wish and start peeking around you will find plenty of side quests and each of them has tremendous depth and unique stories (sometimes sad or gruesome) of their own.
You play the game the way you want to play! If presented with an obstacle you can most certantly find diferent ways of passing it and reach your goal, be it guns blazing, charming your way through, beating everyone up, sneak in without murdering anyway, its your choice, you play the way you want to play!

This is an immersive game, with a dark atmosphere, filled with mysteries regarding both the main and side quest line and the lore itself of the world of Vampire The Masquerade!
From the dark clouds in the nights sky to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s waiting in a alley to the beautiful soundtrack, this game acomplishes in setting the right ambience, dark, violent and seductive!

I cannot express how much I love this game and how much I think you all should play it!
Its a dark, moody game where you are now the social, brutal and sexual beast behind the veil of the world thats hidden from human sights!

reviewText:
An underated gem, VtM: Bloodlines puts you in the role of a newly embraced vampire amid an ever so dark and oppressive world.  The game offers you a selection of clans to play that each offer their own powers and weaknesses to take into account. An FPS with a touch of RPG elements, you'll gain experience over time to invest into a variety of skills and powers to upgrade and master.  There really is no wrong way to play this game, talking and sneaking through most if not entire levels is just as valid as rampaging through with guns and blades provided you have the skills and ability to back it up.  Your dialouge options can vary from clan to clan along with what abilities you can use to manipulate others, which further provides an incentive to replay this game multiple times with different skills and powers to see what other actions play out.

Melee combat switches you to third person giving you a better range of vision as you block, evade, and strike enemies; while ranged fighting allows you to switch to third but also first person for making those more carefully aimed shots.  The stealth mechanic is pretty simple, just crouch and stay around dark areas.  Your stealth skill makes you harder to be spotted and if you get behind someone without notice you can instant kill.

Blood is your source to power abilities and help keep you from frenzying (losing control of yourself), so getting blood is crucial.  You could get it from someone will like a person you charmed at a bar or hire an escort, you could buy bags of blood from some who are willing to sell, or you could even take it from combatents you fight by grappling to overpower them. The options you take are up to you.

Bloodlines also has its share of a few bugs and hiccups for which I recomend you look into the unofficial patch fix which remedies that.  Without spoiling anything, the story is nicely done and definitely worth the playthrough.

reviewText: One of the best ARPG games ever made. It's a flawed gem
date:
as somebody once said. This game gets my highest recommendation, and is one of my all-time favorites.

+ Extremely atmospheric:
Each location in this game leaves a lasting impression. From the music to the aesthetics, this game will draw you into it's dark world and have you enthralled.
+ Interesting, memorable characters:
I can remember the names of many of the minor characters in this game. The characters are all expressive, with interesting dialogue options. I really enjoyed the voice acting.
+ Very high replay value:
There are many different clans to play in this game, all with their own unique abilities and dialogue options. You'll find something new in this game every time you play it.

The only drawback are the bugs, but the worst and most game-breaking of them have been fixed in a fan-made unofficial patch. That said, some bugs still exist, but they're all easily overlooked and in no way stop the progression of the game.

reviewText: This is one of the best RPGs ever developed. Seriously just buy it, it's worth the full price. The quality of writing is above and beyond the vast majority of RPGs out there. Most quests are open-ended and have multiple ways to finish them and each of the 7 vampire clans change the way the game is played, giving it a lot of replay value. This game is as good and possibly even better than games like Morrowind and Fallout 2. It was the first game to be developed using the source engine and because of that it holds up well graphically although there are many mods out there that both add content and tweak up the the visuals. This game went unnoticed when it was released, despite recieving a lot of praise and it does deserve all of that praise. This is seriously one of the best RPGs and games ever developed. reviewText:
I love this game. I played it back when it first came out in 2004. It is now several years old but has held up very well.

In the game you start out with a somewhat lengthy cutscene which gives you an idea of the society you now belong to as a new vampire or childe. You are then released into a somewhat open world to begin your undead life as pretty much everyone's errand person. Your style of play will obviously depend on what clan you chose at the beginning. Whether you are a fighting brujah, beastly gangrel, squishy tremere, smooth toreador, snooty ventrue, crazy malkavian, or *shudders* disgusting nosferatu; you will find plenty to fight in the perpetual darkness.

This game has decent graphics (especially considering its age), great dialogue, believeable characters (and some pretty wild ones too), monsters (other than vampires), plenty of seduction, AWESOME music (seriously though... this game introduced me to several artists that I had never heard of that I still listen to til ths day), and an overall decent and interesting story. One word of advice... explore the cities and talk to everyone... multiple times. There are many interesting side quests that you can easily miss!

It has a few glitches that can sometimes occur in unpatched versions. Only thing I dislike about this game is how many autoaves it produces. It creates a new autosave every time instead of simply rewriting the autosave file. This feature cannot be turned off as far as I am aware. Periodically you will need to go through and clean up the older autosaves.

reviewText:
EDIT: Price gripe in the concluding thoughts.
I don't believe that vampires have been represented in a more interesting way than in this video game. Well, technically a video game based off of a popular table-top RPG known as the World of Darkness containing multiple settings, and one well known one called Vampire the Masquerade. It is essentially vampires trying to conceal their power and blend in with society. Bloodlines is set in early 21st century Southern California with a Gothic and punk combination. Combine all of that with a cast of eccentric and intriguing characters, and a moody, ominous soundtrack you get probably one of the best worlds of any aRPG to date.

Story
A very interesting one for sure. First off, this whole game supposedly takes place soon before Gehenna, a.k.a. The Final Nights. Anyway, with that on your mind you might think, What's the ♥♥♥♥ing point?" when you see the rest of the story. WARNING: Minor spoilers may be ahead. So you start as a freshly embraced (fledgling) Kindred (vampire). This was against the rules of Prince LaCrotch and so he gives your little friend the final death (you're undead
recommended: he decides for you to do chores for him and so you travel all over SoCal doing very odd jobs for vamps and humies alike. The quests are all unique and well crafted

reviewText:
As true a diamond in the rough as any game you can find here. Well, well worth the time of anyone who's interested in RPGs, arcane / urban / supernatural horror atmosphere, good writing in games or good plotting in gaming. If this is on sale you're cheating yourself if you don't give it a go.

The premise in a nutshell: Your character goes on a bender and ends up dead, then undead. Saved from certain (final) death, you end up an investigator / fixer for a secret shadow society of urbane monsters, chasing down all sorts of weird happenings in and around nighttime Los Angeles. Talk, fight, and use your monstrous powers to manipulate or destroy hapless mortals and other, less redeemable things.

Let's start with the good: The plotting, writing, atmosphere are all simply amazing. From the marketing materials and screenshots you might assume the game is grim and gritty and oh-so-goth, but the game is, for the most part, incredibly funny. Think Deadpool or Garth Ennis' comics - there's a lot of black humor. Most everybody is dead and loving it. And it's not possible to say enough about how incredible the voice talent cast is, with a small handful of exceptions. Yes, that's Bender showing you the vampiric ropes in the tutorial. If the premise seems ridiculous at first, the game will sell  you on it. The central mystery is really good and the sense of dread builds perfectly.

The atmosphere of the game is great - much like Deus Ex, it makes the most of being set entirely at night. There is a definite sense of traversing the city of angels' seedy underbelly - while the rest of the world's sleeping, all the weirdos and club kids and dirty cops and streetwalkers come out to play. If you look hard enough you'll find not just other vampires but stranger, more sinister, and inexplicable things preying on humans. the original soundtrack is very good and mostly trip-hop influencedm and the licensed soundtrack (mostly playing in clubs) is, well... It's subpar goth metal, for the most part, but all the files are in .mp3 format so you can switch them out for whatever you want.*

The narrative is composed of several story strands and subplots but is structured in hubs and spokes" - think Hell's Kitchen in Deus Ex or Omega Station in Mass Effect 2. Each city center (there are four) is a large street-level area

reviewText: Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines is a VERY good RPG with a good story and gameplay. Yes it may look a little bad but dont let that put you off this amazing game. Im already on my second playthrough as a Gangrel. The clans of vampires act as the classes with the Gangrel being a meele fighter and the Tremers being the mages. reviewText: Bloodlines is a flawed gem of a game, it had a troubled as hell development and it really shows. The game is a buggy mess, but thankfully fans have patched out a lot of the bugs so make sure to get the Wesp fan patch before you play. To sum it up Bloodlines has some of the best atmosphere, writing, and actual roleplaying in an RPG and it still really holds up to this day. There's multiple solutions through missions and each vampire clan have their own unique skills to solve them, i.e. Nosferatu can turn themselves invisible, Tremere have powerful blood magic, and Malkavians can drive people insane. Sadly, the game falls apart in the end with some horrid forced combat sections (So make sure you have a good combat build going, though just cheating through it is totally fine) but it ultimately is a game worth playing because there are still way too few RPGs that are like it.

reviewText:
This is one of those flawed gems that you most likely never heard about.

An awesome concept with a gritty world involving Vampires, werewolves, conspiracies, choices and lots of ♥♥♥♥ing action.

The game sadly has a fair share of issues; but many I believe have been patched either by the community or devs. I also know it has a modding crew. I'm not sure if they are as active now but none-the-less they have made some.

If you can get passed some of the games clunky mechanics and dated graphics; I'd highly suggest buying at such a low price.

Especially if you are a Vampire and overall supernatural game fan. These are your Ann Rice vampires...Not teeny boppers. Many of them being lustful, sadistic and all the other things you'd expect from people who have lived for 100's if not thousands of years.

The great thing is that you start as a human in the intro sequence. Bitten by either a guy or girl you just slept with (it depends on your choice of male or female).

You're then thrown into the political world of Vampire: The Masquerade. The factions all held together by what would seem to be one man who is a corporate CEO and also a Vampire.

You quickly learn of the society that they protect from the outside world. A society they protect by means of absolute and brutal violence if their common laws are broken.

The most interesting aspect is your choice of character. They range from a high-class, posh and political faction (affecting your characters stats) to a more brutish, borderline anarchist faction. Also; quite possibly my favorite overall are a type of psychic vampires that can often predict the future in pieces. Your dialog reflects it even...The great part about them being that they can barely piece together a sentence that isn't nearly a riddle or pscho-babble.

It adds high replay value. Just with the character choices and your possible responses.

I'd give the game a solid 8/10 at it's state now. On release it was more buggy and almost unplayable at times. But now with the mods and bug fixes thrown in; it's a lot of fun.

Don't pass up a gem like this (albeit a rough one at times). It's good for at least one solid and satifying playthrough.

reviewText:
While suffering somewhat from some bugs and glitches, the game itself is a good challenge, to keep the simple review. You will need to find the patch.
Moving to the more detailed review...
The intial attempts you may make to load the game could end in heartbreak, as the game possesses a bug which prevents you, or at least prevented me, from playing the game without downloading a key patch. The good news is that this patch is available for free online, in fact there is an extended unofficial patch, also available, which does not prevent the game being played on steam. Not that you would be missing much, the game doesn't have 100% steam compatiable 'chieves all over the place, or much else. It's single player, after all.
Once you get into the game you find that there is both a tutorial section - skippable, if you don't mind loosing some work towards stat increases and having to pay for a set of lockpicks - and a guided character creation, which is perfectly good if a little impersonal. You also have the option to set everything yourself, if the guided version did not set things to your pleasure.
And then you get to the story, and that... Well, it's hardly my place to spoil it, especially with it's numbers of little twists and hidden reprocussions.
You should play it if you really want to find out.

reviewText:
Pros:
-one of the few fully fledged RPGs to feature vampires (and I'm not even a vampire fan)
-interesting twist on the vampires - 7 playable clans, each with their own strengths and weaknesses
-nonlinear gameplay - sneak around without being seen or slaughter everyone with a gun
-diverse 'disciplines' (basically supernatural powers) - invisibility, charm, induce insanity and more
-decent dialogue system
-good plot with ingenious quests
-strong cast of characters
-can be witty at times, playing with stereotypes and such
-length - it probably took me around 30+ hours to finish, including most of the subquests (don't mind the hours on record, I often play in offline mode)

Cons:
-the graphics (that is to be expected from a game released in 2004) - clipping issues are unfortunately quite common
-difficulty spikes - very easy at first, can be frustrating at the end depending on what weapons you're using
-lackluster and unbalanced combat system - upgrading your melee comabt skills will only increase the damage you deal, the movesets and attack speed remain the same (or improve just slightly); there is also no good reason to choose unarmed combat over melee weapons
-hubs offer relatively little to do once the sidequests are finished (justified in that you only ever walk the streets at night)
-buggy (be sure to install unoffical patches)
-the inventory can be messy
-price - about 20 bucks for a ten-year-old game that isn't even a cult classic (albeit, for what it is - a very decent RPG, perhaps it should be)

My rating: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Greater than the sum of its parts; an understatement.
On the hunt for another game that plays like Deus Ex (open world, many ways to complete tasks, stealth is almost always an option, etc.),  I fell onto this game.  And I'm both happy and sad about it.

Happy
This game is fun, engrossing, interesting and at times a little creepy.  The setting, SoCal, becomes as much a character as any of the off the wall kindred or kine you meet.  To me, I can't get enough open world games set in present day cities, and this has to be one of the more quirky and shady settings that I've played in recent years.

The gameplay isn't as polished as a game like Deus Ex, but not many games are.  If you get past the dated graphics / character design and the not-so-great combat mechanics, you'll be able to enjoy a big world that has a lot to offer, filled with funny and odd characters throughout.

It's one of those games that after you beat it, you look forward to the next play through a year down the road.  There are a handful of different clans to play as (which can really change the way you play), but as most people suggest, save the Malkavian clan for your 2nd play through for when you already understand the story.

Sad
After you get into the game, learning the basics of the Lore that VtmB has developed over the years, you're bound to want more.  And I want so much more.  This game couldn't be big enough.  I want more chapters, more missions, more locations to explore.  More dangerous encounters.  Hell, take this engine to New York or Chicago or London.  Tell more stories using the already rich World of Darkness universe.

The huge problem with all this is that there hasn't been another video game in the Vampire: The Masquerade (or even World of Darkness) universe since this game; 2004.  With so much dense material to create a story with, it's surprising that it hasn't happened.  I'm not sure I would've been interested in the MMO that got canceled earlier this year, but it would've been better than nothing.

TL;DR - If you want a game that you can take your time exploring, a game that gives you the freedom to go about completing parts of the story the way you want, and don't mind Vampires as a means of telling a story, then please, get this game.

Warning:  Patch this game with the unoffical patch.  It may take awhile, but it's necessary.

reviewText: Highly recommended.  One of the best games I have ever played.  Fair warning, It is buggy, the graphics are dated, and it fizzles at the very end because the devs were rushed to release.  However, moving beyond that, this is a cult gem.  It is the only game that gets the RPG elements and first person perspective nearly perfect.  It is NOT a dumbed down game, it is an actual MATURE game that actually earns the M title.  There is sex, violence, addiction, slavery, and many other adult themes.  It is the closest I have ever seen of an RPG pen and paper game brought to life.\n\nThis should be the standard that all modern RPG/'first person games' should astrive too.

reviewText: The game is nearly ten years old so the graphics are obviously dated but this game is still really solid. It's similar to Deus Ex in that a few months after you complete it, someone somewhere will mention it in passing and you'll curse their name while you reinstall it and play through it one more time. Some parts are really atmospheric while some are extremely frustrating (hollywood sewers, if you used noclip, I don't blame you). The way you can customize your character is really nice too, there are a lot of different combinations you can mess around with. I put 32 hours into it over one playthrough so you can judge for yourself whether it's worth the money, but I certainly enjoyed it. Also, USE THE LATEST VERSION OF THE UNOFFICIAL FAN PATCH, this game is buggy and the patch fixes it.

reviewText:
This game is amazing... buggy as hell, but amazing nonetheless
a fine example of FPS and RPG mixture done right in a non-Borderlands way (I do love Borderlands, by the way)

the story develops really well, as it should in an RPG, and it gives you a play-style totally unique to your senses,
You like to play sneaky and talk your way through things? Good, have fun
You like bashing skulls and punching down your way through the game? Good as well, have fun
You are just a madman wanting to shout a little nonsense into a nonsensical world? Awesome, good for you, have fun!

that said, boy, this game was rushed... with a plethora of game-crashing bugs that will leave you quite ♥♥♥♥♥♥...
the game saves automatically quite often, so it should not be much of a problem anyway... depending on your play-style, that extra drop of rage might even make you an unstopable killing machine

other than that, well worth the promotional price given every halloween, and, for completionists, there is a hell of a lot of content in this baby, with various side-quests triggered in ways quite funny to discover...
also, if you buy it, go after the unnoficial patches... high-res did not favor this game over time... but the fan community tackled this issue quite beautifully (actually fixing some bugs in the process)

even with the bugs, double thumbs up for this game

reviewText:
This game sat in my wishlist for a long time before I decided to play it.  My main concern was that I couldn't be impartial.  I love the World of Darkness games, and was seriously worried that despite the many recommendations this game has recieved, I couldn't help but be disappointed.

I was not disappointed.

Truely, I felt as if I were in the World of Darkness.  The game is a little crowded with WoD lore, but it was fun to see a little bit of everything from hunters to hengeyokai.  The leveling system is almost straight out of the WoD role playing system, which made it easy for me to know what was going on right away.
The game's controls never got in the way of gameplay, but sometimes the camera would get a bit confused when crawling through sewage tunnels.  It was all worth it though.  The first time I let loose with Celerity 5 in a room full of ninjas, all was forgiven.

I've seen a lot of mention of issues getting the game to run well on Windows 7, but I had no real trouble.  I did get the not enough RAM" error
date: but going in and changing the compatibility to XPsp2 fixed that right away.\n\nAll in all
recommended: this is a fun action RPG.  While some of the programming shows it's age
hoursPlayed: the gameplay has aged very well.  I feel that most people will find this game enjoyable
voteText: but if you are a World of Darkness RPG series fan
helpfulPercent: then Bloodlines is absolutely not to be missed."

reviewText:
Alright, for real though, this is a game that has aged very well. It was a golden RPG for 2004, and today is still Golden. With Troika dead, and before Paradox bought out the rights to White Wolf and WOD, CCP didn't do crap with this series including updates, letting other people remaster it, etc. Luckily this game still has a somewhat active, but small, community, and came out with amazing patches even after a decade of death and silence. There was a project to remake/remaster the game called Project Vaulderie, but unfortunately it got shut down by CCP even though CCP had been doing nothing besides working on Eve Online.
The best:
-The music is A1. Introduced me to some good gothic metal bands, and the soundtracks for a lot of the hubs are very pleasing.
-The dialogue is hilarious most of the time, and it changes depending on what clan you are.
-While there was some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice acting, there was also a lot of good voice acting from well known voice actors.
-Clans: There are several you get to choose from, each one has its own special abilities, appearance, and ways you run through the game.
-There is no leveling up, you gain experience points and then assign those earned experience points to certain skills you want to increase, which is a simple and nice.
-Kind of has it's own karma system to put it basically, you kill innocents, you lose humanity, you lose all your humanity, you go into a frenzy which isn't always the prettiest. So most of the time you have to be conscious of your actions.
-The atmosphere was greatly crafted; to be a dark gothic setting. Everything is eerie, not especially scary, but eerie and dark really no matter where you are.
-You get to dance like a maniac.
-You get paid good for a lot of quests.
-A ♥♥♥♥♥ON of lore.
The Bad: A lot of this can be excused because of the time it was released, but still mentioning,
-The map is absolutely tiny. There are only 4 hubs you can go to, which all are pretty damn small and will take you like 10 minutes to run through all the buildings.
-The bugs. Of course, this has to do with the state it was released in, problems with the devs and Valve, etc. But if you don't install the patch that was wonderfully made by fans, then you're going to have a hard time playing because this game is bug heaven.
-A lot of the NPCs are the same, there's probably like 5-7 differen't types of NPCS in one city, with 3-4 repeats.
-The AI is awful. You can have a decent sneak level and be crouching in front of a group of cops that are on a hunt for you and they wouldn't see you.
-The game is fairly short. I think the first time I played this I completed the main and side quests within at least 14 hours.
-You don't really get a choice in who you side with. Throughout the game, you are working for LaCroix no matter if you don't like him, but at the end you do indeed get a decision.
-You can't really replay this game much differently than a last playthrough mainly because in terms of storyline, there isn't too much you can choose differently, besides minor decisions.
-It really doesn't show too much or hint at the enormous amount of lore the WOD and VtM series has. The first time I played this I had no idea that there was a crap ton of books belonging to this series. But luckily, once I found out, I bought all of them.
-Because the environment is small and all the work went into the quests, you really can't do much in terms of just exploring. There's not much to interact with.
-LOOT. There is rarely any loot throughout the entire game. Which any loot you find is sold for dirt cheap and you get barely any $$$.

Overall, a lot of the flaws of this game I can look past because of the age. Lets all hope Paradox does a good job dealing with this series, because it can either go absolutely horribly or incredibly wonderful. And lets hope they don't make a MMO.

reviewText:
This is officialy the best Vampire game ever created. It belongs to a good RPG, horor (creepy kind of horor, no jumpscares) and belive me or not, even the comedy genre. It haves a huge replay value since you have multiple kind of Vampires (clans) you can play as, and they are all different. The biggest spotlight get the caln Malcavian and Nosferatu.
Malcavians because their dialoge options are completly different,  they are all completly insane not to mention speaking to the STOP sign and news reporter over TV, xD.
Nosferatu because of their ugliness you will get a lot of hilarious reactions from NPCs but the penalty for it is you wont be able to do some quests. Technicly, Nosferatu are like the HARD mode for this game.
It haves a many endings so watch the story and try to make good desicions!
And just to mention this is NOT the Twilight teen Vampire ♥♥♥♥, this is some serious Vampire ♥♥♥♥. Now that's done here's the Pros and Cons:

Pros:
-Replay value
-Very fun combat mecanics
-Mucis makes the creepy dark atmosphere even more better.
-Very interesting and special side quests
-Main story is greeat
-RPG part is very well made
-Vampiric powers are awesome and very helpfull and different for every Clan
-Characters are interesting
-I never saw better dialoge options in any video game i ever played in my life and i played them a lot. The cool thing is that every character makes deep facial exsprecions for every sentance they say.
-Cool easter eggs
-and other....

Cons:

-You'll find your self going on internet so see some solutions for quests, since some quests get you more exsperience if you beat them on different way, hidden treasures ect.
-Needs the unoficial patch, but it's a quick job not problem at all.

Overall it's a must play game, shame it never got a sequel :) And watch youre ♥♥♥ when you get to the Seeside Hotel in Santa Monica...

reviewText:
This game is a buried gem. Activision, as per their hitleristic standards, rushed this game into release about halfway through the development. The result is somewhat painful as far as bugs and glitches go. For me, the game wouldn't even start on its own, and when I initially tried to play it, I uninstalled and felt regret for buying it on my boyfriend's recommendation.

A few months afterwards, I installed it again while I had a craving for RPGs. Here's the single key to enjoying this game: go and download the unofficial patch, and make sure to select the patch plus during the installation process. A large amount of the game's content is in unactivated code. The patch is regularly updated - the most recent update was this year, last I checked - which fixes all of the game breaking bugs and readds content that wasn't quite finished or activated.

The game? Great. The lore is excellent, which most of anyone who has experience with the Old World of Darkness universe would know. Even if you're not, the game is a great introduction. I wasn't a huge expert before I started playing, but a few hours in, I pulled up the wiki and simply started reading. The writing is quality. The characters are memorable, and it's hard not to feel about them; usually, if they're not Beckett or Jack, that feeling is indescribable loathing. The quests are so interesting, you feel a need to go out and find all of the ones avaliable. The environment offers many areas to explore and makes you want to explore them.

The only two things I would say aren't perfect about the game are the graphics and the combat. The graphics, naturally, are as dated as the game, and they haven't aged well. I honestly enjoy them because sometimes they're literally laughable. The combat is charmingly schizophrenic, in that you're never quite sure what you're doing, nor what you should be doing, but gosh dang if the results aren't fun. The combat difficulty jerks up and down with little in game conceivable reason, and initially I was confused, but then I realized that the difficulty wasn't based on game mechanics. It's based on lore. If the game makes you fight vampire hunters, no matter at what point you're at in the game, the fight's going to be very hard because vampire hunters in the Old World of Darkness are damned near impossible to kill.

It's a great game, and I think that if lore, missions, writing, and plots are your thing, you should play it. However, don't buy it. Pirate it. A larger company - I think it was Bioware - bought the company that made it and fired everyone who worked on it. Your money would be spent paying the people who ruined the chance of a second game.

reviewText:
An urban environment stylized in gothic fashion? Check!
Love, loss, and revenge bundled into a tale of personal angst? Check!
Dark humor, and a multitude of memorable, well-fleshed out characters with sassy, BAMF, and creepy all represented? Check, checkity, check!
The slaying of vampire stereotypes and a glimpse into the humanity and lack thereof in White Wolf's World of Darkness? Depends on your choices, really.

But...A level scarier than some Nossies? Twists that might make a Tzimisce look twice? Views and individuals that may entrance a Toreador? You'll get all of this and more!

Seriously though, this is one of my top favorite RPGs. The ability to choose from multiple clans and skill sets for your protagonist gives the game a lot of replay value. You're able to unravel different facts and scenarios depending on your choices. Plus, VTMB has superb dialogue (Just ask the Malks! Though the other voices in their head may stifle yours...). I recommend looking for the unofficial patch by Wesp5 that adds to and fixes bugs in the original content though. And although the graphics could be improved, this game was ultimately a wonderful and very fun experience.

reviewText:
Bloodlines takes some getting used to the first time around, but once you have the gameplay down, it's not hard AND it's wicked fun!

+'s
*Story! The story is a lot of fun, and based on what you do, you can have different endings.
*Class variety! There are 7 clans which is the perfect number of classes for a game. Each vampire clan is treated different by NPCs and has a different set of abilites (although some abilites are shared between classes.)
* Immersive! You really feel like you're in the World of Darkness.
*CHARACERS, CHARACTERS, CHARACTERS!
*REPLAY VALUE! Because your character gets treated different, you get new lines of dialogue each time and have to try new strategies for the same quests.

-'s
*Slight glitches can get annoying, but they happened very infrequently and had mostly to do with getting stuck on doors in my case.
*That's pretty much it. This game is GREAT!

reviewText:
One of the best game i have ever played. Bloodlines features every night creature we know and love into one good RPG. Story is really cool and makes you want to move forward. You were bitten and turned, now you discover the underground world of vampires and need to learn how to be one of them. The game have a lot of interesting NPCs and characters for you to interact or feed if you so wish. Has a compelling vampire lore built that does not sound stupid or untrue.

Combat is real time but based on stats (weapon damage + your skills). You have some vampire powers also to use. Boss fights can be a drag, but are not really that bad. You also have a lot of choices and paths to take. You can almost always choose to go peacefull, stealth or all out warfare (depends on skills). Some missions are scary (especially the mansion one, you will know what i am talking about after you played it) and can range from the basic deliver this in there to complex and engaging storylines.

From the start you can choose your race and some features. Add some points in skills you desire. You will also visit different cities and locations.

Warning: The game have a memory problem, meaning if you have more then 2gb memory ram, you will need to download the unofficial patch, which fixes the problem and many others, so i would recommend it even if you can run it vanilla.

The game is fun and fresh, i would recommend it for anyone that likes RPGs and long conversations and choices ala Mass Effect.

reviewText:
This game is a Historical piece for many reasons, the first of which being thta Bloodlines it's one of the best RPG ever made.

Bloodlines launched in 2004 and was the debut of the famous Source Engine, Valve's technology that would later on support nothing less than Half-Life 2. If that isn't enough, the game was the downfall of Troika, a games studio formed by key people from Black Isle, responsible for the first two Fallout games.

The game is deeply hardcore, and completely written for fans of the Vampire: The Masquerade pen & paper RPG. It's a RPG true to the roots, where you spend most of your time exploring, talking and interacting with a world pretty much alive. It not only explores all that it can from the V:tM setting, but borrows everyhting that fits from the World Of Darkness full setting, meaning one can expect to see nothing short of changelings, werewolfs, Kindred Of The East, Mages and who knows what else. The game is full of memorable characters, with decent voice acting and nice models. The quests are very interesting, and tie well with the setting. Surely, this is one of the most ambituous RPG projects ever done, and it's not a surprise that Troika couldn't quite finish it.

A rushed production meant that most of the game wasn't ready by the time it was unleashed upon the world. This resulted in poor reception by the specialized media and worse by players, who where annoyed by semi done quests, lots of bugs and a number of other problems. And since Troika closed doors a few months later, people thought there was no hope.

Nonetheless, a few people could see the jewel inside the oyster and started working on unnoficial" patches that not only fixed the glitches but also unlocked lots of unfinished content and enabled players to enjoy the whole detailed scenario. To accompany that
date: ENB has a cool DX patch that improves the graphics and make the game even more obscure and dark that it already is.\n\nIf you ever played Vampire: The Masquerade with friend
recommended: you owe it to yourself to play the game. If you enjoy true RPGs
hoursPlayed: you won't forgive yourself for not trying this game. The good is so good that you'll be able to forgive the bad."

reviewText: Seriously a gaming milestone, one of the best games I have ever played. Well made and full of character and intrigue it also features the most frightening sequence I have ever experienced in movie or game format to a point where many people opt to skip the section via the console due to its nature (one could argue if you have played through it once you find it more annoying than scary). It has a lot of great writing and acting in it and the downsides to the game are that it was released before Half-Life 2 and as such valve didn't let them use the fully optimized version of the source engine which led to a lot of bugs. Bloodlines was hurried near the end of production as Troika was going out of business and the combat slog toward the end of the game reflects that. Several people continued to work on the game without pay just to get it as finished as it could be. A fan patch might be necessary for you to fully enjoy this free of some odd bugs but you do yourself a disservice missing out.
