reviewText:
A game mired by its rushed release, VtM:B is an alternating 1st and 3rd person RPG about, you guessed it, vampires.
If the developers, Troika, had not been rushed by their publisher, Activision, this game would have been more completed and plagued less by bugs and glitches, on top of that it would've sold better too, considering that its rushed release forced it to compete with the likes of Half Life 2's release all those years ago.

But enough about that, let's talk about the actual game shall we?

Atmosphere and music
The atmosphere in this game is more important in this game than in others in how it effects the overall feel and tone of the game. There a wolves howling in the night, bats flying around, the sounds of screams and glass breaking in scummy parts of town and let's not forget the eeriness that the wind brings. Different music is played for each hub and each combat encounter. The music has a dark, gothic, jazzy, sultry feel to it. It makes the player truly believe he/she is a creature of the night. The bars and clubs have appropriate music in them as well.
However, where the atmosphere falls short in this game is with the people. This game take place in Los Angeles California, a densly populated city. But it just feels empty, there aren't enough people and there are never any cars aside from the taxi cab that occupy the roads. It's not that big of a deal, but it definitely disrupts the atmosphere of the game.

Gameplay
This game does get a lot of praise, and most of it is deserved, but you just can't ignore some of the downright broken and unrefined mechanics of gameplay. Namely combat and stealth, two of the most prominent mechanics in this game. Stealth is just outright broken, enemies are either completely oblivious to your approach or they see you from a mile away. You can shove your sword through an enemy's sternum, spewing blood every which way and his buddy in front of him will just say Huh? Who's there" and give up searching for you after 10 seconds. Or you can be standing in a room with a closed door
recommended: and be spotted by a wandering security guard
hoursPlayed: through a closed door. The stealth in the game is just bad even with the plus patch.\nLet's talk about combat
voteText: it works but just barely. During melee combat which forces you into 3rd person the camera is your biggest enemy
helpfulPercent: it just feels wonky and like I'm being spun around a merry-go-round while I'm swinging an axe. Guns aren't all that better either
votesHelpful: it feels stiff and klunky and until the later missions in the game it's unfulfilling as you hardly do any damage with them.\nOn a more positive note
votesTotal: the voice acting. This game has some of the best voice acting I have experienced in an RPG. The asians in Chinatown sound like actual asians that would live here in America
votesFunny: instead of the terrible stereotypical accent that some games are known for (I'm looking at you Deus Ex). You can hear the emotion and passion in the character's voices. Also
commentsCount: the game only lets you talk to important people. This could be considered a good or a bad thing. In my opinion
column16: it's good. The game only lets you talk to people who have something worthwhile to say which keeps you from wasting time talking to people who repeat the same line over and over again.\nFinally
column17: quests. I can honestly tell all of you that through all the quests I did (and I did almost every single one) I never once encountered a quest I could not complete due to a bug or a glitch
column18:
this is with the unofficial plus patch. So I highly recommend everyone who is thinking about playing this game gets that patch.

Graphics and design
Now
column19: in my opinion graphics are the last thing you should worry about when choosing whether or not to play a game. But I feel it's worth talking about it in this game. It looks decent at 1920 x 1080 resolution. But there are some hiccups when it comes to playing this game. Certain areas (the warrens
column20: Santa Monica) will drop in framerate due to rain or water
column21:
which is bad. There's also a glitch where if you're not looking in a certain direction the top or bottom of the screen will blur textures together. Easy to fix but still annoying.

Story
Last but certainly not least
column22: the story. In the beginning you are forced into the world of vampires and supernatural beings. You get little to no guidance and it is clear from the very beginning that you are stuck in the middle of a political struggle and you have to decide who to back. On top of that the ever looming subject of an apocalypse is carried through the winds of the night
column23: putting everyone on edge. Doing all of the side quests on your first playthrough should take you anywhere between 25 to 30 hours to complete.\nThis game is NOT for children. There are a lot of adult themes and subjects
column27: and graphic deaths. Not for the faint of heart. Overall the story is strong from start to finish. You will laugh
column30:
but you'll have a hell of a time doing it.

The verdict
Overall I give this game a 8/10. This is by no means a masterpiece or the best game ever
column31: but when it comes to the vampire genre this is probably the best thing you'll ever experience
column32: other than Castlevania of course. It would be a crime for any self-respecting RPG fan not to play this. It's worth the 20 bucks."

reviewText:
One of the hardest parts of writing any good review comes from writing the review itself. Every person has their own appeal, games they like and dislike, and reasons for those likes and dislikes. Not every game a reviewer will play will conform to those likes or dislikes, and a review must still compose himself and present a fair and balanced review in spite of his personal thoughts. I bring this up because it is very difficult to talk about Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines (hereafter referred to simply as ‘Vampire') without delving into the subjective elements it presents without sucking all the emotion and personality from the review and transforming it into a technical overview of the game itself. As such, I have divided this game up into two sections, an objective and a subjective one. But first an overview of the game itself;

In Vampire you play as a young person living in L.A. who has recently been transformed into one of the undead. Upon your indoctrination you quickly come to discover that the vampire society needs to be very secretive about how they act so as to keep the public unaware of their actions. Before long, though a sarcophagus which may or may not house the remains of a very ancient and very powerful vampire is uncovered and the various vampire clans in the city all begin a secret war of cloak and dagger tactics, each trying to recover the sarcophagus and its contents or deny them to others for themselves, all while trying to keep their very existence secretive from humans.

Firstly, for the objective. The game is VERY well designed and it shows in its game mechanics. Serving as a action RPG with elements of The Elder Scrolls (except less open, confining the player to four primary districts that are fairly small and multiple dungeons) it is solid right from the get-go. From the beginning you are forced to select one of a series of vampire clans, each offering its own unique set of bonuses, abilities, and disadvantages that will end up shaping how you play. I, personally, ended up going with Clan Ventrue which focuses a lot on persuasion, but can't feed off of animals and can only feed reliably on upper-class humans. Someone else may end up with Nosferatu which can't raise their appearance at all and has to avoid being seen at all by humans for example.

The gameplay itself is fairly solid with most of the controls being very tight and having almost no real problems beyond a few glitches (which I will cover later) which I can't blame on the controls. One of the interesting things is that, instead of leveling up stats like strength and such, the player instead levels up various skills and abilities which, in turn, affect stats. This can cause for some very interesting outcomes where a character may choose to level up a skill they don't intend to use at all to bolster another skill which they do, in fact, use and results both in a large amount of flexibility and interesting builds as well as a drive to experiment around and see what else can be done.

Another interesting thing is that players do not gain experience from killing enemies in the slightest, but rather from quest completion. This puts an added drive to complete even simple sidequests as the added experience is the only way to make your character stronger.

Lastly, there are two special meters that will need proper attention. The Humanity meter and the Masquerade meter. A large focus of the game is the focus on struggling against the vampire urges and keeping ones self ‘human' despite needing to drink human blood in order to survive. Certain actions can cause players to lose some of their humanity and, as the gauge lowers to 0, it can result in them becoming utterly feral. Meanwhile, keeping the humanity high can result in a weaker vampire who struggles with their new nature. Additionally, keeping ones actions as a vampire secretive is very key and, every time a player is caught being a vampire in public, it costs them on the Masquerade meter. They start with a set amount of chances and, if those chances ever all disappear, game over (going feral wastes a chance). This puts an added focus on keeping ones nature as a vampire truly secret and staying human as going feral at the wrong time on a player who didn't try to keep hidden can cause an outright loss.

Visually the game is fairly solid as well. While, sadly, you won't be able to delve too deep into the many complexities of polygon count, it very successfully manages to convey the feeling of the World of Darkness (the world as a vampire sees it). Vampire does its best to drive this home too, but manages to back it up with some solid displays. While they may look a bit dated today, there is a HUGE difference between ‘dated' and ‘bad' and this is most certainly not the latter.

There are some problems with the game though. First off it seems to revel in giving vague directions and not giving you anything resembling a quest-marker. While this wouldn't normally be too bad of a thing it is very easy to end up lost and unsure of where to go or who to talk too, especially if you stop playing the game for a week or more and don't remember the location of an important NPC with the lack of a map (aside from some bus-stop signs) driving the annoyance home. But, more overbearingly, is the glitches. There are a LOT in this game, and they are NOT of the minor kind. These are the kind that can destroy a game and leave it unplayable. Hunting down a patch and/or activating the command console may very well be a requirement for this game.

And now for the subjective. This is a dark game. A VERY dark game to say the least. The game makes sure to reinforce this with such locations like abandoned hospitals, scummy apartment buildings, sleazy motels, brothels and night clubs galore, and death around every corner. The streets are almost never clean and are littered with trash, bums and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s seem to be the most common ‘professions', and so forth. People looking for a game about sparkling vampires, or even just ‘normal' vampires may find themselves off-put easily. This is a very dark and pessimistic game, and it ended up causing me to rethink about how to score this.

To say that this is a bad game simply because it's world is so scummy and grim is shortselling what the game does right. In any other setting where you can count the number of people who are ‘good' on more than one hand this probably would have been an amazing title. However, this game does not hide for even a moment that this is a grim and depressing world. People not looking for this sort of thing specifically can very easily end up becoming disguised and/or offended by it. Even the ending of the game seems to love rubbing in just how dark this world is.

As a result, I feel it is VERY important to look into the game before buying it and deciding if you wish to play a game like this. While it can be enthralling for people who revel in its darkness, for those people looking for even the tiniest ray of light and hope, they would be better off searching elsewhere.

In summery: while a solid game that is mired by some technical problems, its subjective aspects and story may simply be so off-putting to a player who does not enjoy its dark and grim world as to not make this game recommendable on a whim. If you buy this game, you should know what you're getting into, because this game is in no way shy about tossing you into the shadows.

My pricing: For someone looking for a dark game: 15-20 bucks. It's very solid, if a bit dated and dealing with bugs.

For someone not: Avoid at all costs. Remember, this is a game where it is possible to lose because you couldn't pretend to be a human being instead of a blood-sucking monster well enough.

reviewText: Highly recommend this to people who are fans of FPS/RPG hybrids like Deus Ex, Dishonored, Dead Island, or E.Y.E. To get an idea of how much value you get from it, an average playthrough clocks around 30-35 hours, and your beginning choices of vampire clan massively influences how the game world responds to you, what dialogue you can do, and in some rare instances limits or allows you to complete certain quests. The missions and levels are almost all nonlinear, allowing for a good time with almost any directed character build.\n\nDefinitely worth the money if it's on sale, but PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE don't forget to pick up the Unofficial Patch that will make the game playable on modern systems and restores a lot of cut conent.

reviewText:
Remember when vampires weren't some glittering fairies? VtM:B remember!

But seriously, the game is one of the most brilliant RPGs I ever played.
So what makes VtM:B so great? Foremost, the gripping plot with twist and turns; secondly, a very balanced (IMHO) grinding-free RPG system; thirdly, the fact that every vampire clan has its unique features and abilities, which means replayability (and lots of it) and last, but not least, the gothic/noirish atmosphere of the setting.

reviewText:
LOVE this game.

It look old and it's a bit janky (particularly combat using firearms, melee is must more rewarding) but the world is amazingly well constructed and highly immersive.

This is a world you can get lost in with multiple play style options and great ways to have a completely different experience. If you've already played through and want something different picking a different clan can give open up options and pathways that you previously couldn't have found. Great examples of this are the Nosfertu which prevent you from being seen by human without incurring penalty making you spend the game learning the under paths of the hub areas and the Malkvians who, being insane, replace all of your dialogue options with entertaining non-sequiturs and giving different dialogue from NPC (usually remarking that you're insane).

Just make sure you get the unofficial patch which fixes a range of issues and greatly improves the game.

reviewText: OK, first off, you will most likely need a patch just to run this game. Unfortunately when this game was originally released it was full of bugs & I guess Steam doesn't provide any fixes but don't worry there is a solution. Go to the forum or the website patches-scrolls and install Wesp5's patch version 8.9. This person has done amazing work to not only get this game running but provided many fixes for any in-game bugs. And it's worth the extra bit of time it takes but first off the bad stuff. The first thing you will notice are the outdated graphics but they really are not that bad and you get used to it pretty quick. The worst thing is combat. It's a bit clunky.....actually, it just plain sucks but not so bad that it's unplayable. The thing is VTMB is billed as an RPG & it not only delivers but it may be the best game ever in this aspect if you like getting immersed in an excellent story. There are rules you have to (un)live by & consequences if you don't. Decisions you make early on reflect what happens later. Basically, in a nutshell, it's an RPG that truly allows you to roleplay who you create & that's what makes this game shine.

reviewText:
This game cannot be compared to other games of the same ilk, and it truly saddens me that the company that made it went under, This game brings you on a story following a young man or woman forced to turn into a vampire and his/her following adventure. Now I don't wish to spoil too much of them game but I will say it lets you choose between seven different playble clans each with their own inherent powers and personalities and even more clans that you see in the world. The mthical creatures in this game aren't cookie cutter definitons and each has its own uniqueness that adds character to the game.

The game plays a mixture of rpg elements, such as getting points to add to skills of your choice, getting and saving humanity so that you don't turn more beast than man, and following the masquerade, a set of rules to follow so you dont bring unwanted attention to the vampires. The game also employs first and third person aspects; in first person you get to control the gunplay and you will be spending most of your time looking this way, but in third person you can control your melee aspects which are done extraordinarily well. As in most rpg games you have an inventory in which to keep you weapons, cash, artifacts and other miscellaneous objects in,

To say this game is good is an understatement and I still beat myself up for not playing it sooner, and the game only gets better with mods. I am giving this game 9.5/10. Play this game asap.

reviewText:
It's easy to forget they used to make games like this that don't have that generic console feel we've been putting up with since around 2008.  Dated graphics are the price of entry but if you can get past that you have a terriffic semi-open world with a fantastic story, superb voice acting, varied environments and cool gothic theme (which I wasn't even into but this game sucked me in).

This is basically the only game that comes close to replicating the overall feel of the original Deus Ex, but also stands entirely on its own.  And like Deus Ex, despite the semi-open world mechanics, you never have that feeling that you're just playing a collection of minigames.  All the main and side quests feel tightly coupled to the story.

Vampire was released the same month as Half Life 2 and was therefore totally missed by the gaming public but if I had the choice of replaying both games it would be Vampire, no question.

reviewText: Such a good game! True its dated, true it needs a patch ( which can be gotten here http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647/61625/61626/download ) and yes even then some people still have issues running the game on newer systems. But is it worth it. White Wolf has always been one of my favorites when it comes to table top games, and when they made the first Vampire video game ( Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption released in 2000 for PC ) I played it for ages. Also played the 2 games they released for the xbox for Hunter : The Reckoning. What im trying to say here is I'm a big White Wolf fan so my opinion my be slightly biased. Ether away, the game is great in my opinion. Great story telling, awesome dark atmosphere, and great RPG elements. The combat system is a little clunky but they maybe just due to the fact that in game im still a flegling (new vampire) and still working on my skills. In the end if you are a vampire fan at all, or just a fan of dark evil worlds this game is well worth the money.

reviewText:
This game is a Historical piece for many reasons, the first of which being thta Bloodlines it's one of the best RPG ever made.

Bloodlines launched in 2004 and was the debut of the famous Source Engine, Valve's technology that would later on support nothing less than Half-Life 2. If that isn't enough, the game was the downfall of Troika, a games studio formed by key people from Black Isle, responsible for the first two Fallout games.

The game is deeply hardcore, and completely written for fans of the Vampire: The Masquerade pen & paper RPG. It's a RPG true to the roots, where you spend most of your time exploring, talking and interacting with a world pretty much alive. It not only explores all that it can from the V:tM setting, but borrows everyhting that fits from the World Of Darkness full setting, meaning one can expect to see nothing short of changelings, werewolfs, Kindred Of The East, Mages and who knows what else. The game is full of memorable characters, with decent voice acting and nice models. The quests are very interesting, and tie well with the setting. Surely, this is one of the most ambituous RPG projects ever done, and it's not a surprise that Troika couldn't quite finish it.

A rushed production meant that most of the game wasn't ready by the time it was unleashed upon the world. This resulted in poor reception by the specialized media and worse by players, who where annoyed by semi done quests, lots of bugs and a number of other problems. And since Troika closed doors a few months later, people thought there was no hope.

Nonetheless, a few people could see the jewel inside the oyster and started working on unnoficial" patches that not only fixed the glitches but also unlocked lots of unfinished content and enabled players to enjoy the whole detailed scenario. To accompany that
date: ENB has a cool DX patch that improves the graphics and make the game even more obscure and dark that it already is.\n\nIf you ever played Vampire: The Masquerade with friend
recommended: you owe it to yourself to play the game. If you enjoy true RPGs
hoursPlayed: you won't forgive yourself for not trying this game. The good is so good that you'll be able to forgive the bad."
voteText: January 15, 2013
helpfulPercent: true
votesTotal: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Seriously a gaming milestone, one of the best games I have ever played. Well made and full of character and intrigue it also features the most frightening sequence I have ever experienced in movie or game format to a point where many people opt to skip the section via the console due to its nature (one could argue if you have played through it once you find it more annoying than scary). It has a lot of great writing and acting in it and the downsides to the game are that it was released before Half-Life 2 and as such valve didn't let them use the fully optimized version of the source engine which led to a lot of bugs. Bloodlines was hurried near the end of production as Troika was going out of business and the combat slog toward the end of the game reflects that. Several people continued to work on the game without pay just to get it as finished as it could be. A fan patch might be necessary for you to fully enjoy this free of some odd bugs but you do yourself a disservice missing out.

reviewText: It's a great game, I LOVE it. Uses a REALLY old version of the Source engine (IIRC, this game was released a bit after HL2 - Troika went down a long time ago, no official updates). You'll need an external, community patch for the game to run properly (or at all, if you use a 64-bit system with over 3GBs of RAM - otherwise, variables will overflow and it will fail the memory check). But it's a great game, another display of Source's flexibility. Recommend.

reviewText:
While I've not played any game taking place within the Vampire: The Masquerade universe, I was pleasantly surprised by the attention to detail this game in particular had. It was a unique experience, giving me a more contemporary feel of vampires in modern settings, even ones as ugly as the Nosferatu. Hell, even  finding vampires of Asian descent  was an interesting thing to find out. Not to mention how long the game is and how extensive some maps could be, Bloodlines proved to be an adventure worth finishing. That being said, there were some parts of the game that just felt either...off or just broken. While it didn't detract from the overall experience, they were buggersome to have to deal with. Let's break this down into two lists: Pros and cons.

Pros:
Intriguing story. The ability to mold your path by the choices you make and the factions you choose to aid make the game replayable quite a few times.
Multiple paths. As stated above, you can go a completely different route the next time you play just to see how things would've ended.
Playstyles. While some types excel in some fields, you're completely capable of being any build you desire, which is a nice bonus to have when figuring out what you wish to be good at. Unfortunately some builds just don't work as the game progresses, which I'll cover below.
Theme and enviroments. The world is pretty well done. I didn't expect source to be capable of this kind of detail, major props to the devs. When you walk into the different maps, the different atmosphere feels refreshing too.
Characters. I was impressed by the characters and the people voicing them. They were really aggressive and sold their roles enough to make me wish they had more to say. Honestly, I feel this is the biggest selling point of this game.
Cons:
Combat. Gotta say, the combat in this did not age well. It just didn't feel very engaging to shoot jerkfaces from a distance, nor was it fun to engage in melee combat against things that could very well kill you. The weapons were fun, sure, but it felt somewhat boring.
Builds. You can pidgeon-hole yourself if you do not build your character correctly. If you go mostly charisma, you will melt later on. Buffs don't seem to make much of a difference if you don't focus your points into boosting them, which can either interfere and flatout make your build a mess. Imagine having to fisticuff a boss but doing almost no damage. Argh.
Story and ending. While interesting, the story felt like it tossed elements at you without really explaining much. Like  the werewolf attack . And while multiple endings exists, only one is worth bothering for, and even that can strain the nerves.
Bugs. There are some game-busting bugs that were never fixed in the official release and either need a third-party tool to fix or flatout cheat to get past some triggers that just do not function anymore, which was a big detractor for me.

That said, the game is pretty solid and still fun to play, even today. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone looking to play a game involving vampires and guns.

reviewText: Troika may not have the best track-record for putting out the most stable games, but they certainly have a handle on excellent writing and storytelling. The unofficial patch takes care of nearly all the bugs and restores additional content that was left out of the retail release. RPG elements are implemented a bit differently than most RPGs, in that xp is only awarded for completing quests, so there's no grinding involved, or even leveling (as xp is used to increase stats). The variety of vampire 'clans' that can be played provide a high replay value, as the dialogue options and events vary depending on which you choose. If you enjoy the subject matter, this is definitely a recommended purchase.

reviewText: One of the funnest games in my library. There's loads of options to choose from, featuring rebels and insane prophets to play as. Either way, action and stealth lovers alike are sure to have fun with this game.\n\nMy only problems with it are that it can be really glitchy, so it would be best if you went and downloaded the unofficial patch, which fixes problems for newer systems while also adding new quests and weapons.

reviewText:
Now this is one enjoyable RPG. I liked the gameplay, the story, the music, everything.  Sure, the graphics are really outdated, but if like me you can look past it, you'll definitely enjoy this game. An epic Lacuna Coil song plays when the credits roll, as a perfectly fitting little treat in the end :D

Update: It's 2014 and I'm playing this game again. What can I say, I love it, with all its little flaws - it's mostly graphics, for example characters displaying weird at times like feeding etc, or the way everyone walks ('foxy' :D)... trifles, trifles. To run the game I'm using the unofficial patch for Win7 64-bit along with high resolution display patch.

Here's a link to get everything up and running, I had no problems whatsoever: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2025035

To sum up, I still recommend this game for its story and atmosphere. No sparkle bs here. ;)

reviewText:
What can i say about this game...

Imperfect beauty.
Even with all the glitches, bugs, and any other annoyence within the game, it is one of the best RPGs i have ever had the pleasure to play. This game straight up toppled Fallout from my list of RPGs i love, and took the spot of number 1.

The game itself is low detail, with many bugs (at one point random furniture spawned throughtout certain areas, and if i looked into the sky i would see what looked like the shadows of furniture and people in the sky xD) but the bugs would rarely effect gameplay and since the game saves after ohmost every time you leave a Building you can take a few steps back, if you ever come across a bad bug that really stops you in your tracks. I only ever had one bug that was like this but i didnt even need to load to a previous point cause it was done for me when i was killed by a couch xD(invisible wall kinda deal).

Now if you have been reading up on this game you know that it was never really polished off cause of the developers departure from gaming, luckily a rouge developer by the name of wesp5 took it upon himself to create an unofficial patch that rounds off quite a bit and adds in a few things previously unavailable.

Now a lot of people can play the game without the patch but i see no reason not to get it since it adds more to the game(just a little bit). Some people are afraid of going outside of steam to fix their games but its not that hard to find a reputable site.

I got my patch from http://patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647 and remember to download 9.0 and install it into steam (itll try to install it into a file that dosent exist i.e if you actually had this game on a CD)

reviewText:
The atmosphere in this game is unmatched. I have vivid memories of walking around in-game Los Angeles, taking in the night-time view and looking up at the sky for longer than I care to admit. Numerous other locations are also worthy of praise, with the Ocean House Hotel deserving special mention for being one of the scariest experiences I've ever had in a video game.

The different vampire clans you can play as provide plenty of replayability, and I've played through this game more times than I can count. In particular, Malkavians and Nosferatu make for the most unique experience.

The base game is a bit buggy, so track down the latest version of the unofficial patch before you get started. With this installed I haven't had any issues to speak of.

Although the graphics are a bit dated now, this game is the most underrated RPG I've ever played. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys RPGs, vampires, or simply a good story.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game is quite old, so the graphics are not all that. You will also need to download a fan-made patch to make it work properly, but once that's sorted the game works just fine.

You get to choose one out of seven clans, your gender, and if you want - a backstory. All of these will have an impact on your playthrough, and gives you a lot of diversity to play with. Each clan has different abilities and traits. Sadly, you don't get to customise your appearance though, it's set by your sex and clan.

The dialogue options allows you to voice your opinion, often in a rude way. The game gives you the options you need to go around and be an a-hole to everyone, and you can of course lick butt if that's more of your style. There will also be unique dialogue options based off your clan, stats and abilities.

As you play through the game you will eventually be part of a story of politics, intrigue, and the fight for power and gain in the city. You will get to choose through your actions the outcome of this struggle, which I found very satisfying as you can make the ending of the game directly reflect your opinion on the conflicting factions of LA. There is no black and white answer here, as all these factions could be considered bad in different ways.

All in all it's a good experience, and I highly recommend it.

Oh, and one last bit of advice: Do not open the sarcophagus.

reviewText:
This game is something that is very unfortunate. It has a seriously interesting world, that will imerse you regardless of whether you're a fan of gothic culture or not. It spins a vampire tale that is both interesting and enjoyable at the same time. The plot remains solid and tense up until the 75% mark and then it feels unfortunatly rushed. I ended this story, feeling satisified of the journey but the overal end just left me feeling like alot of choices I made didn't matter. This is of course, due to the game developer being rushed to finish the game on time and highlights of game gems such as this one, are unfortunatly not given the extra attention they deserved.

Gameplay is very similar to that of games like Deus Ex. You are allowed to tackle objectives in any way you wish, in fact the game presents you with a series of classes which almost define your playstyle from then on. And this isn't just a minor state boost ethier. Playing as a particular class for example, renders you unable to travel on the streets due to your inability to blend in. The consequence of this is that you spend most of the game in sewers eating rats, but have a massive advantage when it comes to any stealth encounter. This is one of the fantastic game design choices the games makes! Certain vampire classes have advanatges in certain areas. Some are good at meddling with humans, others are better at combat and violence. One class is considered insane, and has an entire dialouge choice to back it up in conversations.

Combat can be a little worse for ware, but it isn't unplayable. The broken AI, doesn't tend to put up much of a fight - especially in stealth sections. When you pick your class, you will find it difficult to progress down any other path. Stealth classes, tend to be killed quite easily if you try full frontal combat. Stealth isn't just a one off thing ethier, it is supported by stealth kills, shadow blending etc.

Overall, when you play this game - it is very difficult not to appreciate it, for what it could be and for what it is. I find it difficult to discredit the game up to the 75% mark. After that, things are obviously rushed, everything becomes more combat focused and you will find yourself struggling if you didn't pick a combat class. Before that though, is a game that definatly rewards player choice in both story and gameplay. It provide an interesting, immersive gothic world that will delight both those who enjoy vampire culture and those who don't, alike.

reviewText: Do you like Western RPGs, with stat points and characteristics out the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to spend points on? We got that. Do you like free-roaming environments with limited exploration yet tons of things to interact with and discover? We got that too. Do you love being a mother♥♥♥♥ing gun-toting vampire? That's what this game is all about. With the fantastic community patch and an experience you can enjoy thrice (with two classes that add additional content or challenges to the already existing game world) you won't want to put this game down for a good while. Sit back, crack open a blood bag, and enjoy all the alpha Source engine has to offer in quirks and oddities with the best WRPG ever made. You won't regret it.

reviewText: I love this game and had to buy it again just to have it on Steam. It's a somewhat old game in new clothes, but it still has one heck of a story and lots and lots of brilliant characters, not to mention a lot of twisted, sick quests :) I really love the whole night time atmosphere with its whacked out radio shows playing and so on. And it just has so much replay value due to the different clans you can play as (not to mention the gender option - female vampires have a kinda sexy way of taking their night snacks). The music is great too, varying between atmospheric to industrial.\n\nI think the devs should perhaps clean up a bitmap or two on this new release, because the various maps - especially useful as Nosferatu as you'll be hitting the sewers a lot due to their unsightly appearance - are not clear. If you can find the maps online do print a copy if you're playing as Nosferatu. Even with these cosmetic issues it's still a wonderful game.

reviewText:
A game every RPG fan should play.

It takes place in LA, putting you in the shoes – or heels – of a freshly made vampire. They have a secret society and live among us with a certain set of rules to maintain order and ensure that their existence won't become widespread knowledge. This is the Masquerade. You become the new pawn for the local leader in his political wars. Not all is well in vampire community, and some factions are eager to change things.

It's a comfortable entry – just as you're in the dark, so is your character, letting the two of you learn together who's who and what's what in vampire life. It's a pretty crazy one, too. Violence and sex are plentiful and the game doesn't shy from either. You'll find it hard, and not too rewarding, to play your regular Good Hero sort. It's also a very humorous game with plenty of moments that made me chuckle. The voice acting is terrific and there are many great characters. I found myself often just standing still and listening to the in-game news report on the TV, or the late-night radio show for the laughs.

The story develops in unexpected ways and the ending managed to surprise me. Maybe I haven't found them out yet, but I didn't feel as if my choices bore significant consequences. It didn't really bother me, though, because the ride was a good one. The game is divided into city hubs that open one at a time after plot checkpoints, and you can jump from one to the other freely once they're available. You won't find the trademark collect 10 donkey tails" side-quests that pollute fantasy RPGs
date: but instead many fun investigative missions outside the main plot. Backtracking can be annoying
recommended: though.\n\nWhile the story isn't too divergent

reviewText:
Every time someone mentions it, someone will reinstall it.

This is one of the most enjoyable games you'll ever play. Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines is first person and third person action RPG based of the pen and paper RPG of the same title(Vampire the Masquerade). You play as a fledgling vampire who was spared after your sire was executed, now you have to fight the beast inside you by keeping your humanity and obey the laws of the masquerade.

Story 10/10
This game has amazing writing. From the get go you got yourself into some vampire politics and have a whole new world around you that you have to discover. There's not only kine and kindred (humans and human like vampires) there are also things like the sabbat, werewolves, vampire hunters, etc. The main vampire government are the Camarilla, but their are also vampire rebels known as the Anarchs. As the story progresses you'll have to pick a side. Beyond the main story there are countless side missions that often have mini stories or side stories to them.

Gameplay 9/10
It's got a lot of buggy issues to the game but there are several 'unofficial' patches to the game that can help. I can't compare the vanilla game with the patched version because I installed the patch before playing it. But mainly there are various mechanics to the game, from simple combat like shooting and melee attacks, disciplines which are basically spells, you have a blood bar you regenerate from drinking blood, you have a humanity bar you need to keep balanced, and finally the masquerade bar. Knowing the names of the mechanics is one thing, figuring and mastering them is another.

The game is very immersive, depending on what clan you are and what you do and say to people effects how you are treated by various characters throughout the game. The game allows you to have your own play style, from sneaking around vents to going guns a blazing, and seducing or threatening people you talk to to get information. There are also the little things that make this game so amusing as well, for example I mercilessly murdered a fat guy at a diner and I heard the sounds of sirens and the police were waiting outside, I also broke into an art gallery and a mission later watched a news reporter talk about that very thing. Great stuff!

Music 10/10
The music is top notch! Composed by Rik Schaffer & various others, the game has many tracks to fit the mood. From ambient tracks for the streets of LA and haunted hotels to Club tracks by actual bands and slow tracks to strip clubs. I absolutely love it!

Over all: 9/10
VtMB is an amazing game to have. I personally found it hard to stop playing, and within two and a half days already had 25 hours of play time. Even though I make this sound like a masterpiece it does have it's negatives like the need for a patch to properly work, it gets a bit hard/confusing at times to find stuff or complete objectives, or the fact there's not enough Jeanette(play the game and you'll know what I mean ;P)! ::I almost forgot to mention this game has lots of sexual content, it almost surprised me. So if you're not into that kind of thing or just don't like it in general I would highly consider that a factor before thinking about buying this game::  But this is still something to have, especially if you're into vampires or just Action RPG's in general. So I urge you to check it out!

reviewText:
This game is one of my all-time favorite RPGs on the face of this earth. I was never into vampire silliness prior to my discovery, but if you're looking for a 3rd person, multi-faceted, gritty / noir-styled action RPG with visceral, albeit clunky, gameplay, then this is it.

Mind you, it's a tad dated at this point and certainly has its fair share of flaws, but literally, there's a console-activated cheat that can make the ♥♥♥♥ (breasts) of a certain clan of female vampire expand to be as big as your screen- /no make/. Who cares if they're all glitched and polygonal? What are you, some kinda queer?

In short, VtM:B is dated, occasionally glitchy and has a somewhat ponderous fighting mechanic. It also boasts incredible variety, either in how one approaches obstacles (seducing, coercing, persuading, mind-♥♥♥♥ing, murdering, sneaking, exploding, exsanguinating); or what style of character you choose to get it all done with (seven clans of vampire in this iteration of the series and both genders per); or the arsenal of weaponry you can utilize (I'm talkin' katanas, shotguns, flamethrowers, sledgehammers and bush hooks, submachine guns, SEVERED ARMS, et-♥♥♥♥in'-cetera)...

PHEW. Anyway, do yourselves a favor and BUY THIS GAME.

(NOTE: even the Steam version of this game seems to hate certain versions of Windows? 7 in particular, as I've not been able to play it on my current computer, as noted by my utter absence of play time)

reviewText: Resurrected as a vampire after your death, you are recruited to assist in an ongoing war of attrition between several vampire clans who vie for control of Los Angeles. Using a combination of stealth, cunning and brute force, only you can ultimately shape the result of the conflict.\n\nFamously released in an unfinished state (though several patches and mods have been released that largely fix this), Bloodlines is a flawed yet absolutely captivating gem of a game that takes the stealth-action RPG hybrid gameplay of series such as Deus Ex and Thief, drapes it in a veneer of equal parts Anne Rice sensual horror and goth club sleaze, and ties it all together with an excellent script dripping with lore, mystery, sexuality, and violence. There's plenty of replay value to be had as well thanks to the diverse array of vampire clans one can play as; from the seductive Toreador or traditionalist Ventrue, to the monstrous Nosferatu or gibbering and insane Malkavian. Just be ready to do some patching after you've installed the game.

reviewText:
With the latest unoficial patch and a few compatability tweaks, the game is stable, plays at 1920x1200, is quite nice to gaze upon, and is one of the deepest RPG experiences out there. Each character class really does mean a different experience. The game is dark, funny, has a rich story, and some great voice work. It was marred by a flawed launch and lost under Half-Life 2.

Just look for it on sale, do the little bit of work needed to run in Windows 7 64 bit, and then revel in some vampire RPG goodness.

Oh, play the game one as any character other than a Malkavian or a Nosferatu. Then try it as both. See, it really is different. One can't be seen by mortals (Nosferatu) and hides in shadows and hte sewers and the other is bat-crap crazy.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game is quite old, so the graphics are not all that. You will also need to download a fan-made patch to make it work properly, but once that's sorted the game works just fine.

You get to choose one out of seven clans, your gender, and if you want - a backstory. All of these will have an impact on your playthrough, and gives you a lot of diversity to play with. Each clan has different abilities and traits. Sadly, you don't get to customise your appearance though, it's set by your sex and clan.

The dialogue options allows you to voice your opinion, often in a rude way. The game gives you the options you need to go around and be an a-hole to everyone, and you can of course lick butt if that's more of your style. There will also be unique dialogue options based off your clan, stats and abilities.

As you play through the game you will eventually be part of a story of politics, intrigue, and the fight for power and gain in the city. You will get to choose through your actions the outcome of this struggle, which I found very satisfying as you can make the ending of the game directly reflect your opinion on the conflicting factions of LA. There is no black and white answer here, as all these factions could be considered bad in different ways.

All in all it's a good experience, and I highly recommend it.

Oh, and one last bit of advice: Do not open the sarcophagus.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros:
1. This game has tons of options for character cutomization. Different vampire clans, each with their own advantages/disadvantages make each playthrough unique.
2. Many different dialogue options. Conversations with characters can go different ways depending on what you choose.
3. Interesting and engaging storyline.

Cons:
1. Know that this game has MANY bugs. It took me multiple tries to get it to work. First, there was an issue with space, then its display settings had to be changed, then it couldn't connect to steam etc etc. It's a pain and takes a while to work them all out, but so many people experience it that you can find the solution easily.
2. The character outfits are sort of glitchy. I doubt this will bother some but I noticed it with certain clothing options.
3. I didn't really care for the more action-oriented aspects of the game. I ended up just trying to get through combat areas quickly so I could get back to the story.

This game is a lot of fun and I would definitely recommend it. However, you have to be willing to go through the process of weeding out the bugs. Like I said, there are a lot of them, but the game is worth it.

reviewText:
Probably the best vampire based game I've ever played (which isn't saying much, because I haven't tried that many vampire based games - they appear to be in short supply), but still...

Based off the World of Darkness system, this game, while it has it's flaws, is surprisingly fun. An enjoyable, highly immersive RPG, with a lot of choices to make in terms of character creation and dialogue. Great stories (both side- and main-quest), containing some genuinely chilling moments.

If you're tired of the vampires being all sparkles and no substance, play this game.

reviewText: I remember when the first, Vampire PC game came out. It was such a fun, emmersive game, that when the sequel hit, I almost wet myself. It's such a great blend of 1st person with RPG, and takes you so many places in the deep, seedy underbelly of L.A., as you massacre your way through levels filled with ghosts, mutants, werewolves, and cultists. It's too bad the game hasn't been updated for a long, long time. It's worth a lot more than one or two playthroughs, and is full of several paths, interesting characters, and amazing level design.

reviewText:
While I've not played any game taking place within the Vampire: The Masquerade universe, I was pleasantly surprised by the attention to detail this game in particular had. It was a unique experience, giving me a more contemporary feel of vampires in modern settings, even ones as ugly as the Nosferatu. Hell, even  finding vampires of Asian descent  was an interesting thing to find out. Not to mention how long the game is and how extensive some maps could be, Bloodlines proved to be an adventure worth finishing. That being said, there were some parts of the game that just felt either...off or just broken. While it didn't detract from the overall experience, they were buggersome to have to deal with. Let's break this down into two lists: Pros and cons.

Pros:
Intriguing story. The ability to mold your path by the choices you make and the factions you choose to aid make the game replayable quite a few times.
Multiple paths. As stated above, you can go a completely different route the next time you play just to see how things would've ended.
Playstyles. While some types excel in some fields, you're completely capable of being any build you desire, which is a nice bonus to have when figuring out what you wish to be good at. Unfortunately some builds just don't work as the game progresses, which I'll cover below.
Theme and enviroments. The world is pretty well done. I didn't expect source to be capable of this kind of detail, major props to the devs. When you walk into the different maps, the different atmosphere feels refreshing too.
Characters. I was impressed by the characters and the people voicing them. They were really aggressive and sold their roles enough to make me wish they had more to say. Honestly, I feel this is the biggest selling point of this game.
Cons:
Combat. Gotta say, the combat in this did not age well. It just didn't feel very engaging to shoot jerkfaces from a distance, nor was it fun to engage in melee combat against things that could very well kill you. The weapons were fun, sure, but it felt somewhat boring.
Builds. You can pidgeon-hole yourself if you do not build your character correctly. If you go mostly charisma, you will melt later on. Buffs don't seem to make much of a difference if you don't focus your points into boosting them, which can either interfere and flatout make your build a mess. Imagine having to fisticuff a boss but doing almost no damage. Argh.
Story and ending. While interesting, the story felt like it tossed elements at you without really explaining much. Like  the werewolf attack . And while multiple endings exists, only one is worth bothering for, and even that can strain the nerves.
Bugs. There are some game-busting bugs that were never fixed in the official release and either need a third-party tool to fix or flatout cheat to get past some triggers that just do not function anymore, which was a big detractor for me.

That said, the game is pretty solid and still fun to play, even today. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone looking to play a game involving vampires and guns.

reviewText:
This game is one of my all-time favorite RPGs on the face of this earth. I was never into vampire silliness prior to my discovery, but if you're looking for a 3rd person, multi-faceted, gritty / noir-styled action RPG with visceral, albeit clunky, gameplay, then this is it.

Mind you, it's a tad dated at this point and certainly has its fair share of flaws, but literally, there's a console-activated cheat that can make the ♥♥♥♥ (breasts) of a certain clan of female vampire expand to be as big as your screen- /no make/. Who cares if they're all glitched and polygonal? What are you, some kinda queer?

In short, VtM:B is dated, occasionally glitchy and has a somewhat ponderous fighting mechanic. It also boasts incredible variety, either in how one approaches obstacles (seducing, coercing, persuading, mind-♥♥♥♥ing, murdering, sneaking, exploding, exsanguinating); or what style of character you choose to get it all done with (seven clans of vampire in this iteration of the series and both genders per); or the arsenal of weaponry you can utilize (I'm talkin' katanas, shotguns, flamethrowers, sledgehammers and bush hooks, submachine guns, SEVERED ARMS, et-♥♥♥♥in'-cetera)...

PHEW. Anyway, do yourselves a favor and BUY THIS GAME.

(NOTE: even the Steam version of this game seems to hate certain versions of Windows? 7 in particular, as I've not been able to play it on my current computer, as noted by my utter absence of play time)

reviewText:
It's easy to forget they used to make games like this that don't have that generic console feel we've been putting up with since around 2008.  Dated graphics are the price of entry but if you can get past that you have a terriffic semi-open world with a fantastic story, superb voice acting, varied environments and cool gothic theme (which I wasn't even into but this game sucked me in).

This is basically the only game that comes close to replicating the overall feel of the original Deus Ex, but also stands entirely on its own.  And like Deus Ex, despite the semi-open world mechanics, you never have that feeling that you're just playing a collection of minigames.  All the main and side quests feel tightly coupled to the story.

Vampire was released the same month as Half Life 2 and was therefore totally missed by the gaming public but if I had the choice of replaying both games it would be Vampire, no question.

reviewText: I mostly love this game for the world created for it, and the stories contained within that world. Besides that, it's got memorable characters, a good soundtrack and can be funny at times, both on purpose and accidentally (keep in mind this was released in '04). Combat gets repetitive pretty quickly, so I suggest trying to kill enemies without being detected to make things a bit more intense. I also suggest to not bother with guns and stick to melee (always collect any dropped weapons though, so you can sell them later). Plenty of sidequests to keep the main narrative from getting boring, great character sheet. I recommend the hell out of this game.

reviewText: Seriously a gaming milestone, one of the best games I have ever played. Well made and full of character and intrigue it also features the most frightening sequence I have ever experienced in movie or game format to a point where many people opt to skip the section via the console due to its nature (one could argue if you have played through it once you find it more annoying than scary). It has a lot of great writing and acting in it and the downsides to the game are that it was released before Half-Life 2 and as such valve didn't let them use the fully optimized version of the source engine which led to a lot of bugs. Bloodlines was hurried near the end of production as Troika was going out of business and the combat slog toward the end of the game reflects that. Several people continued to work on the game without pay just to get it as finished as it could be. A fan patch might be necessary for you to fully enjoy this free of some odd bugs but you do yourself a disservice missing out.

reviewText: If you play RPGs not only for incredible loot and skill tree leveling, but also for the sake of role-playing a character and taking in the atmosphere, this is the game for you. While you do gain experience, and unlock new abilities, the skill tree will be unfamiliar to those not already versed in White Wolf's pen and paper games. Also, there is very little gear, whether dropped or bought and it almost feels scripted. You get to a new place, and get a new weapon or armor, at the same time on every character you make. The only other bad point i'll touch on is the combat system. While it's fun hacking away in melee, and the vampire powers you get to back your fighting skills are top-notch visually and mechanically, if you specialize in guns, expect to have a REALLY hard time until about halfway through the game, even if your ranged skill is high. On top of that, even when your wielding a trusty baseball bat knocking some punk to the floor, you literally have to wait for them to get up to strike again as the hit-boxes don't register when they are prone. But those a few minor annoyances, and really aren't the spirit of the game. You can get through many missions without physical confrontation if you are socially inclined, or can make people magically go insane. The characters you meet all have a story and each one's personality might clash with another or even yourself. It's a great opportunity to really role-play a vampire and a must have for anyone looking for more than a run-through guns blazing type of game.

reviewText:
A Classic RPG with a mature rating, a bunch of bugs, and patchs. Be sure and read the forums for this game BEFORE purchasing.

I had to apply some patches before I could run the game on a Windows 7 SP 1 machine. Once the game was patched it is a joy to play. There are multiple paths through the game and a pseudo open world environment to explore. There are multiple endings based upon the players choices. Decent replayability as well.

I did experience a few bugs in the game that required switching to a developers console to work around. No show stoppers, just a few nuisances.

The game may not run on Windows 8 | 10 and above based upon a report from Microsoft's Upgrade Assistant. The good news is that the game will run in the WINE emulator.

If you enjoy classic RPG games with multiple story lines and are not put off by the need to apply patches and work around a few bugs, then grab this game and enjoy.

reviewText:
Probably one of my favorite games ever.
It was released in an unfinished state but that can be fixed with a patch since the game has had lots of attention from fans for over a decade.
So what is it all about?
Well, you are basically a random person turned into a vampire. After this you get introduced to the vampire society and the game starts.
Amazing game overall, it has aged really well.
The voice acting is amazing and all the side quests are fun in their own way.
There are seven different vampires you can choose to play as. All with different pros and cons.
I'd recommend playing through as any clan but the malkavian and then replaying the game as a Malkavian.


So... Yeah, I recommend this game

reviewText:
Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.

Long name, incredible game. Quite possibly the best game I have ever played. I have reached the final boss several times, but only finally got around to giving him his Final Death today. Taking around thirty hours, this is a game complete with an amazing story, interesting characters, cool powers, and the most legit vampire's I know of. The basic story begins with your 'embrace' - where you become a vampire - and continues as your rise in power and prestige, until you are causing the events, rather than reacting to them.

Each of the nine clans you can choose from have different abilities. They could be considered classes, similar to other games, but they aren't usually wildly different. Most of the change is in the player models, and the powers - each clan getting two powers from a pool, and a third unique to their clan. But there are enough differences to make replaying a possibility. For example, the Nosferatu are hideous, and as such cannot seduce people for blood, and instead have to suck on rats in the sewers below the streets, while the Ventrue clan is the opposite - they cannot drink from rats due to their nobility. Another is clan Malkavian; each and every one of them is insane. Incredibly, they have 100% unique dialogue, opposed to other clans having a few lines or opportunities each, and can engage in some interesting tangents - such as having a conversation with the news reporter on TV.

While the vanilla version is very buggy - due to the developers being rushed in their final stages - most of these issues can be resolves with the fan made Unofficial Patch, which is a must-get if you plan on playing. It's not the prettiest game either, with some pretty terrible animations at times, but all this is forgiveable in the face of such a wonderful experience. The game uses Valve's source engine (an earlier version of the engine Titanfall is built on), and was released on the same day as Half-Life 2; and though the models in the game are by no means of equal quality, they are attractive in their own way, and help nail the bleak, horror/noir atmosphere.

If Firefly was a game, it would be this one. While the themes are not at all similar, it is the kind of game that when someone brings it up in conversation, or you read about it on the net, you pretty much have no choice but to reinstall and have another crack at it.

10/10. I honestly cannot think of any way to improve it, other than give the devs more time to improve a couple of the cutscenes.


tl;dr - V:TM-B is one of the best games ever. It is often on sale on Steam. buy it. Install the most recent Unofficial Patch. Enjoy the ♥♥♥♥ out of it.

P.S. ♥♥♥♥ the haunted hotel. The game isn't all that scary (though some bits are somewhat disturbing), the hotel always gets me.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Favourite game, and has been for a few years.
Fun, quirky, clever, and the graphics really aren't that bad at all for its time.

It can be extremely buggy, even game-breaking at times, but the fanmade patch usually fixes those problems. Combat is relatively simple. It's important to remember you can't be a jack of all trades. There's very limited EXP in the game (which is why I suggest playing all of the side-quests) so it's best to spec into things.

The characters are cool. There's several factions you can join. Playing as different clans can prove to be a new experience (especially Malkavians, Nosferatus and Tremere, but my favourite is Gangrel as bland as it is.) I find characters like Jack and Gary to be hilarious. There's a great voice acting crew, too. Most of the voice actors sound like they put some real heart into it. Though the generic NPCs that roam around sometimes sound like they used a less-than-moderate quality microphone and didn't care.

All in all, I think this game is 10/10. Just make sure you patch it before you play it or you're going to have a bad time.

reviewText:
This game pretty much makes up for every one of its shortcomings, and there are plenty, through pure style. There are some fantastic fan mods that even out the rough edges, but even unmodded this is one of the most immersive games out there, one that throws you into its world and lets you explore its darkest reaches. Rather than excessive exposition, it lets you discover the ins and outs of the underground vampire society yourself, much as an outsider like the player character would have to do. It has a fantastic amount of player choice, and a genuinely good storyline to follow, however you choose to play.

Many of the core mechanics are pretty sloppy, and the various skills are terribly balanced. Not to mention an excess of bugs can impede your progress. But if you can ignore, or mod out these issues, you'll find it's the perfect vampire game. Just as the Arkham games make you feel like you really are Batman, this makes you really feel like a vampire. And makes vampires cool again in the process.

(As usual, ignore my low recorded playtime, as I've already played my non-steam version multiple times.)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Well, where do I begin, telling you about this gem? I suppose I'll start with what it is.

Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is an action-RPG based on the tabletop game of the same name. Gamplay-wise, it plays similarly to the original Deus Ex, leaving multiple options to accomplish your objectives. You could go for the good-old fashioned direct assault, use stealth, or alternatively talk your way out of situations. It's really up to you.

There are numerous vampire clans to choose from, all with their own unique focus. Brujahs and Gangrels focus more on combat, whereas the Tremere make use of powerful blood magic, and the Toreador and Ventrue manipulate their way towards their objectives. There are, however, two more, special clans. The Nosferatu are mutated horribly by their vampiric curse, and must skulk around the sewers and alleys lest they be seen. Needless to say, they're good at stealth. And last, but certainly not least, are the Malkavians. These guys are completely insane, which is reflected in game by your bizarre dialogue choices, hallucinations and voices in your head. They do have some nice powers, though, such as invisibilty and Dementation, which is useful for both dialogue and enemies. You'll also be treated quite differently based on your clan, leaving a lot of replay value.

Really, though, it's the story and atmosphere which make this game truly special. Walking through the streets of a depiction of LA apparently going through it's Goth phase. The hubworlds are small in size but full of detail, and you always feel like you're doing something different. From tracking down and killing a cabal of blood disease-spreading vampires, to exploring a haunted house, to getting your own ghoul (basically someone who has recieved vampire blood and gets some basic vampire abilities from it, but not the whole set), it always feels like you're doing something unique. It feels good to drink blood, and the political intrigue of the secret vampire society you're involved in is extremely engrossing, and all the characters have different personalities, and a good few are quite memorable. The story moves at a good pace, although the story path to a seemingly simple objective often becomes quite convoluted.

Sadly. this game is not without its flaws. First off the bat, there's the bugs and poor optimisation. This game was Christmas rushed (which, as we all know, always ends well), and the game was in an extremely buggy state upon launch, and Troika were unable to fix it on account of going bust shortly after. The game will ouright refuse to work on some modern systems without an unofficial patch, and may be almost unplayable. Even with the patch installed, you will see bugs often. Most won't affect gameplay, but will pull you out of that fantastic atmosphere Troika worked so hard to make. After a certain point close to the end of the game, due to it being rushed out the door, the game forces you into a repetetive series of combat arenas, with no alternative paths. So, if you've not been putting points into combat skills, you're screwed. The final boss (oh, and the boss fights aren't very good throughout the game) is impossible to kill without a gun, when guns are next to useless for a good part of the game. Oh, and even if you have gone the combat route, the game still has a massive unfair difficulty spike near the end. The combat itself is bearable, but very repetetive, and essentially consists of wailing on attack and spamming your most powerful clan Disciplines.

Still, overall, VtM-B is easily one of the best RPGs ever made, and you owe to yourself to get it. Accept the Embrace and find your place in the world of the Kindred...

reviewText:
A fantstic RPG dragged down by a few flaws which are completely fixed by the unofficial patch. This is what RPGs should be. Never mind my play time as I have owned it before my Steam copy and the unofficial patch stops counting your game time. I have gottens hundreds of hours out of this game and still plan on getting hundreds more.

Pros:
+Beautiful dark modern fantasy world with vampires, werewolves, rock golems, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s
+You would be suprised at just how much freedom this game gave players for its time
+The Voice acting is nothing short of phenominal
+Controls very well
+Hours upon Hours of game time

Cons:
-Combat is lackluster, nothing like, say Morrowind Combat but it could have been better
-The second half of the game does get a bit more combat focused
- Can't get Jeanette to repeat her introduction speech :(
- Never ever getting a sequel :(

All in all, if you're not familiar with this game you're in for a treat.
If you are well then you know exactly what you're in for so try the newest unofficial patch, it's a great one.

reviewText: Resurrected as a vampire after your death, you are recruited to assist in an ongoing war of attrition between several vampire clans who vie for control of Los Angeles. Using a combination of stealth, cunning and brute force, only you can ultimately shape the result of the conflict.\n\nFamously released in an unfinished state (though several patches and mods have been released that largely fix this), Bloodlines is a flawed yet absolutely captivating gem of a game that takes the stealth-action RPG hybrid gameplay of series such as Deus Ex and Thief, drapes it in a veneer of equal parts Anne Rice sensual horror and goth club sleaze, and ties it all together with an excellent script dripping with lore, mystery, sexuality, and violence. There's plenty of replay value to be had as well thanks to the diverse array of vampire clans one can play as; from the seductive Toreador or traditionalist Ventrue, to the monstrous Nosferatu or gibbering and insane Malkavian. Just be ready to do some patching after you've installed the game.

reviewText:
A lightening pearl in a World of Darkness, which I had forgotten eventually for ten long years. In December 2004, I installed this game for the first time, but at that early point in time, this game was released unfinished. At the same day, i happily uninstalled it to never play it again because of the heavy load of bugs and crashes.

10 Years and a lot of unofficial patches later, in December 2014, I bought this game on Steam for 5€, installed the 9.2 patch and completed it with much joy in 43 hours, with no frustrations at all and even without having to use a single cheat. Even installed on a Windows 8.1 x64, the game did only crash twice, both times in the very beginning while configuring my character.

I enjoyed every minute of it, and I will certainly play it again in the future. Who could have ever imagined this game would become such a Cult Classic? A must-have for fans of RPG, vampires or just all good PC games.

reviewText:
Oh boy, where to begin?

Vampires : The Masquarade : Bloodlines is one of those games that become classics the moment you turn them on. The closest thing I could relate it to, both in terms of gameplay and overall feeling is the first Deus Ex, as in both games you are some kind of superhuman who gets to master disciplines and powers in an RPG fashion in a game that gives you complete freedom in how to tackle the problems it throws at you (The third Deus Ex could qualify as well, but it tends to make the various intended paths obvious to you right off the bat, rather than letting you think of creative approaches yourself), and each clan (read : Character class) helps complement those playstyles.

I'm not really going to say much more, because at this point, you should know whether the game interests you or not, but know this :
- Steam only provides the retail version of the game, which is notoriously buggy (not just minor stuff, I'm talking about the game being outright unbeatable or just crashing all the time) because Activision insisted that the game be released the same day as Half Life 2. This version only includes the most critical fixes, like getting the game to start on computers with more than 1GB of video RAM. You definitely should download the unofficial patch (which actually includes official" fixes) at this adress : http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647
- As enjoyable as I found the experience

reviewText: Troika may not have the best track-record for putting out the most stable games, but they certainly have a handle on excellent writing and storytelling. The unofficial patch takes care of nearly all the bugs and restores additional content that was left out of the retail release. RPG elements are implemented a bit differently than most RPGs, in that xp is only awarded for completing quests, so there's no grinding involved, or even leveling (as xp is used to increase stats). The variety of vampire 'clans' that can be played provide a high replay value, as the dialogue options and events vary depending on which you choose. If you enjoy the subject matter, this is definitely a recommended purchase.

reviewText:
This game cannot be compared to other games of the same ilk, and it truly saddens me that the company that made it went under, This game brings you on a story following a young man or woman forced to turn into a vampire and his/her following adventure. Now I don't wish to spoil too much of them game but I will say it lets you choose between seven different playble clans each with their own inherent powers and personalities and even more clans that you see in the world. The mthical creatures in this game aren't cookie cutter definitons and each has its own uniqueness that adds character to the game.

The game plays a mixture of rpg elements, such as getting points to add to skills of your choice, getting and saving humanity so that you don't turn more beast than man, and following the masquerade, a set of rules to follow so you dont bring unwanted attention to the vampires. The game also employs first and third person aspects; in first person you get to control the gunplay and you will be spending most of your time looking this way, but in third person you can control your melee aspects which are done extraordinarily well. As in most rpg games you have an inventory in which to keep you weapons, cash, artifacts and other miscellaneous objects in,

To say this game is good is an understatement and I still beat myself up for not playing it sooner, and the game only gets better with mods. I am giving this game 9.5/10. Play this game asap.

reviewText: One of the funnest games in my library. There's loads of options to choose from, featuring rebels and insane prophets to play as. You can also make things harder on yourself and play a Nosferatu, who can't even walk topside without terrifying the citizens. The game also has loads of dialogue options that effect how people interact with you and what quests are available. Plus both stealth lovers and gun fanatics can have fun, with both being great choices for getting most jobs done. Either way, action and stealth lovers alike are sure to have fun with this game.\n\nMy only problems with it are that it can be really glitchy, so it would be best if you went and downloaded the unofficial patch, which fixes problems for newer systems while also adding new quests and weapons.

reviewText:
A Classic RPG with a mature rating, a bunch of bugs, and patchs. Be sure and read the forums for this game BEFORE purchasing.

I had to apply some patches before I could run the game on a Windows 7 SP 1 machine. Once the game was patched it is a joy to play. There are multiple paths through the game and a pseudo open world environment to explore. There are multiple endings based upon the players choices. Decent replayability as well.

I did experience a few bugs in the game that required switching to a developers console to work around. No show stoppers, just a few nuisances.

The game may not run on Windows 8 | 10 and above based upon a report from Microsoft's Upgrade Assistant. The good news is that the game will run in the WINE emulator.

If you enjoy classic RPG games with multiple story lines and are not put off by the need to apply patches and work around a few bugs, then grab this game and enjoy.

reviewText: A great game.  I had never heard of this game until I saw it on sale during Halloween, and then watched a video where Total Biscuit called it one of, if not the best RPG games ever made. It definitely makes for interesting dialogue.  An interesting story, cool combat.  You are a vampire, living in the modern world, in a big city.  You do not want to let humans know of your existence, and that is what the masquerade" is.  Pretty cool game."

reviewText: This game is far from perfect, but it is also fantastic. For an old broken game that should NOT have aged well, it has somehow managed to do quite the opposite and be a refreshing and immersive RPG experience. There is a surprising amount of depth and a wide range of options for how to build your character, allowing for new and interesting experiences even through multiple playthoughs. You will meet a variety of characters, most of which are very memorable and leave a lasting impression (even if that impression is that you want to drain them dry on the spot...I'm looking at you, Patty).\n\nYou will not be impressed by the fighting mechanics, it is janky at best and flatout broken at worst, but you also won't care. The setting, the soundtrack, the NPCs, the simple joy of feeding from unsuspecting humans...it all adds up to something special and fun that you won't regret giving a shot, so just do yourself a favor and buy the hell out of this game.

reviewText:
Favourite game, and has been for a few years.
Fun, quirky, clever, and the graphics really aren't that bad at all for its time.

It can be extremely buggy, even game-breaking at times, but the fanmade patch usually fixes those problems. Combat is relatively simple. It's important to remember you can't be a jack of all trades. There's very limited EXP in the game (which is why I suggest playing all of the side-quests) so it's best to spec into things.

The characters are cool. There's several factions you can join. Playing as different clans can prove to be a new experience (especially Malkavians, Nosferatus and Tremere, but my favourite is Gangrel as bland as it is.) I find characters like Jack and Gary to be hilarious. There's a great voice acting crew, too. Most of the voice actors sound like they put some real heart into it. Though the generic NPCs that roam around sometimes sound like they used a less-than-moderate quality microphone and didn't care.

All in all, I think this game is 10/10. Just make sure you patch it before you play it or you're going to have a bad time.
